171666,The role of human glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase in reactivating oxidized forms of the DNA repair enzyme APE1,Ramotar  Dindial,"Ramotar, Dindial",CIUSSS Est-de-l'Ile-de- Montr&eacute;al-Maisonneuve Rosemont,Qu&eacute;bec,Canada,200809,355206.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Clinical,Cancer Research,Cell Biology; Dna Repair; Neurological Diseases; Oxidative Dna Damage; Oxidized Proteins; Protein-Protein Interactions,"Project summary:
Reactive oxygen species are highly unstable molecules and are produced, e.g., by mitochondrial respiration and activated
neutrophils. These reactive oxygen species can attack and destroy various cellular macromolecules such as proteins or
enzymes to cause functional inactivation, thereby leading to several human disorders, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis,
Down's syndrome, and Alzheimer's disease.
Previous research: (What has been done already?)
We discovered that the protein GAPDH can form an association with the DNA repair enzyme APE1, which functions to
maintain the integrity of the genome. We show that GAPDH converts the inactive form of APE1, that is, the oxidized APE1
caused by reactive oxygen species, to the active form that is needed to repair damaged DNA. Reducing the level of GAPDH
decreased the activity of APE1 and caused the DNA to accumulate lesions. Such lesions if not repaired can initiate the
formation of cancer cells.
Project description: (What is being studied and how the study will be conducted?)
We believe that GAPDH has the ability to maintian the redox state of a key DNA repair enzyme APE1. We plan to show that inactivated APE1 is unable to process in vivo DNA lesions and therefore causes a range of biological consequences. 
Impact and relevance: (How will our studies help?)
We predict that GAPDH may act to protect APE1 protein which is susceptible to reactive oxygen species-induced
structural damage. We believe that this is required in neurodegenerative diseases such that it prevents accumulation of genotoxic lesions that could trigger cell death.  Moreover,
defects in GAPDH function might serve to predict individuals who are at risk of developing cancers",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171666&lang=en
171677,"Somatic and Psychological Symptom Focus in Asian-Canadians: The Role of Cultural and Individual Differences in the Psychopathology, Assessment, and Treatment of Depression",Ryder  Andrew G,"Ryder, Andrew G",Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (Toronto),Ontario,Canada,200809,300000.0,CIHR New Investigator,Salary Programs,Social / Cultural / Environmental / Population Health,"Neurosciences, Mental Health and Addiction",Alexithymia; Culture; Depression; East Asian; Quantitative; Somatization,"East Asians in Canada are often stereotyped as a model minority, with few psychosocial difficulties. The reality is that mental health problems in this population are underestimated and often treated inadequately. This problem has serious implications, both for the health of East Asian Canadians and also for the social and economic well-being of the country.

Recent research in East Asia and Canada has demonstrated that Euro-Canadians are more likely to present psychological symptoms such as depressed mood, whereas East Asians are more likely to present somatic symptoms such as fatigue. As a result, Western-trained clinicians in Canada are more likely to under-diagnose depression, with consequences for treatment and for the prospects of recovery. What is not clear, at present, is why these cultural differences are observed.

This project aspires to go beyond simple descriptions of cultural variation in an effort to unpack the underlying reasons for these different symptom emphases. In particular, these studies will examine the ways in which cultural values, beliefs, and assumptions shape one's focus of thinking - either internally, on one's on thoughts and feelings or externally, on other people and on social groups. Focus of thinking, in turn, is thought to influence the symptoms that depressed individuals focus on and find most distressing.

Understanding the reasons why East Asians and Euro-Canadians tend to emphasize different symptoms while depressed will not only improve the ability of Canadian clinicians to conduct more accurate assessments of depression in East Asians, but will also help us to develop culturally-sensitive therapies. The result will be quicker and more effective intervention, reducing the burden of depression on the patient, the family, and Canadian society as a whole.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171677&lang=en
171685,Deciphering novel roles for the acetyltransferase NuA4 in genome stability.,Baetz  Kristin K,"Baetz, Kristin K",University of Ottawa,Ontario,Canada,200809,334071.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Biomedical,Genetics,Chromosome Stability; Functional Genomics And Genetics; Lysine Acetyltransferase; Proteomics; Septins Organization; Spindle Pole Body And Microtubule Dynamics,"Project Summary: Every time a cell divides, it must accurately distribute one copy of each duplicated chromosome (DNA) to each daughter cell. Errors that cause cells to gain or lose chromosome, chromosome imbalance, is a hallmark of and a likely cause of cancer.  Dr. Baetz's laboratory uses the simple model organism yeast to identify and characterize proteins that are essential for maintaining chromosome balance. 

Previous Research:  The powerful techniques available in yeast has allowed for the Baetz laboratory to systematic assess the role of each yeast gene in chromosome stability.  This lead to the identification of an enzyme complex named NuA4 which when mutated,  resulted in dramatic loss of chromosomes.  

Project Description: The NuA4 complex regulates the functions of ""target"" proteins by the addition of small chemical modification call an ""acetyl"" group.  Presently the ""target"" proteins of NuA4 are largely unknown. In order to begin to understand how NuA4 is regulating chromosome copy numbers, the Baetz laboratory is attempting to identify new targets of NuA4.  Once targets are identified, they will asses if these are the important targets in maintaining chromosome stability. 
 
Impact and Relevance:  The yeast NuA4 complex is remarkably similar to the human NuA4 complex which has been implicated in numerous cancer types.  Therefore, discoveries that the Baetz lab can quickly make in yeast will provide insights into the role human NuA4 plays in cancer progression.  Increasing our knowledge of genes that prevent chromosome imbalance will significantly advance our understanding of cancer and help in the development of effective new treatments for the disease",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171685&lang=en

Such bacteria use special toxins to alter the control systems of our cells.  These toxins cause drastic changes to the membranes of our cells, forcing them to internalize the bacteria and in the process providing them with a specialized compartment that allows the microorganisms to replicate inside our cells.  Salmonella, best known for its ability to cause 'food poisoning', is one type of bacteria that can parasitize our cells in this manner.  In this study we will examine how a Salmonella toxin, called SopB, can alter cellular membranes to invade our cells.  The membrane alterations caused by SopB are related to those that occur during other human diseases, including cancer, bipolar disorder and Type 2 diabetes. rheumatoid arthritis. It had long been thought that amyloid formation was the result of interactions between proteins that had
folded incorrectly, and that these interactions were toxic to cells. New research, however, is showing that not all amyloids
are toxic, and that there exist 'functional amyloids'. These functional protein aggregates appear to play important roles in a
wide variety of biological systems, including skin pigmentation and microbial development/pathogenesis. Our work focuses
upon on one class of functional amyloids found in the bacterium Streptomyces coelicolor. The 'chaplin' proteins of S.
coelicolor interact to form amyloid fibres on the bacterial cell surface, and are critical for bacterial development. We are
working to understand how chaplin interaction is controlled, as it is thought that precise regulation of expression and
aggregation is a key factor in determining whether an amyloid is functional or toxic.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171695&lang=en
171701,"Psychometric testing of a new scale measuring medical outcomes of dysphagia (MOD) in adult patients with swallowing disorders secondary to stroke, cervical spine abnormalities and head and neck cancer",Martino  Rosemary,"Martino, Rosemary; Streiner, David L",University of Toronto,Ontario,Canada,200809,430461.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Clinical,Aging,Adults; Dysphagia; Lung; Measurement; Nutrition-Hydration; Psychological,"Swallowing disorders (dysphagia) are common in adult patients. There is emerging evidence that dysphagia itself can cause adverse medical outcomes. There is a three-fold increased risk for pneumonia in these patients versus similar patients without dysphagia. Patients with dysphagia also suffer poor nutrition and dehydration. Patients can become so malnourished that it slows their recovery. Dysphagia can cause choking when food or liquid enters the lungs. Over time, this will cause pneumonia and even death. More acutely, patients fear that their choking will cause them to suffocate and die. Over time, patients are embarrassed to be seen choking and thus feel forced to dine alone. These patients report feelings of isolation and depression. To date, there are no practical methods to assess these adverse outcomes of swallowing difficulties in patients. This research will be the first to address this gap. Specifically, as part of previous research (PhD dissertation by RM, the PI) a new measure of medical outcomes of dysphagia was developed, titled the Medical Outcomes of Dysphagia (MOD) scale. The MOD consists of 3 subscales that each measure lung, nutrition-hydration or psychological consequences in patients with swallowing difficulties. Unlike more expensive and complex tests, the MOD has been designed for both in- and outpatients. This research will validate each MOD subscale to ensure retention of only items that are reliable and valid for use with patients who have dysphagia due to stroke, cervical spine abnormalities or head and neck cancer. The final MOD subscales will be the first to allow clinicians to track medical complications in their patients and to ensure that treatment is effective. Globally, the MOD subscales will direct limited health care resources to the most effective treatments for swallowing disorders.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171701&lang=en

Over the past 2 decades, evidence has accumulated demonstrating IP profiles of cancer cells are distinct from profiles of normal cells and alterations of cellular IP profiles can beneficially impact the cancer phenotype. With clear and growing evidence that the IP profile of cells change with cell proliferation and modulation of this profile can control proliferation of cancer cells, we ask the question: What is the best way to target IP signaling to utilize these anti-cancer effects?
  Previous studies have revealed modulation of IP signaling promotes apoptosis and increases the effectiveness of anti-cancer drugs in numerous cultured cell and animal cancer models.  These studies have concentrated on IP6 as a pro-apoptotic signal and potential anti-cancer therapeutic. However, there is no strong evidence identifying IP6 as the direct, active agent. In fact, this idea is refuted by reports that over-production of IP6 in cells lead to the inhibition of apoptosis.  Clearly, the model of IP6 as a pro-apoptotic signal must be reevaluated.  To explore new approaches to modulate IP profiles and promote apoptosis, we hypothesize actions of IP kinases, which comprise the IP6-synthetic pathway, counteract pro-apoptosis signaling, and by inhibiting these kinases we can promote apoptosis and mimic the pro-apoptotic actions of IP6. Currently, there are no chemicals available to inhibit IP kinases and explore their roles cancer cells.  We propose to overcome this obstacle by engineering IP kinases, such that we can control their actions using chemicals.  This will provide valuable and novel insight into the IP signaling pathway and the roles of IP kinases in cancer. Subsequently, one of the main events is the clumping of tiny cells termed platelets along the exposed plaque within a blood vessel artery that supplies blood and oxygen to either the heart or brain. Platelets are required for the normal stoppage of blood flow when cuts and injuries occur. However, when they clump together in an uncontrolled manner within an artery the consequences can be devastating. There are two proteins COX-1 and COX-2 within the human body that control the production of two fat-derived molecules known as thromboxane and prostacyclin. These substances regulate how platelets clump together. We do not know exactly where and when COX-2 is found within blood vessels and during the process when platelets are made. We will study a specially designed mouse with a fluorescent COX-2 protein to examine where it is found. Novel mouse strains in which the two COX forms are exchanged will also allow us to investigate how the two proteins function to control platelet clumping when a blood vessel is injured. A special microscope technique can be used to visualize blood vessels in live mice and to follow the developing clump of platelets (thrombus). We will use innovative techniques (gene and cell therapy) to deliver prostacyclin so as to prevent or limit the damage when a thrombus forms. This research is important because it will help us to understand the basic mechanisms of thrombus formation and how the two COX proteins function, which may lead to new treatments for cardiovascular disease.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171709&lang=en

First, images are acquired using either
magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or positron emission tomography (PET), a compound detectable by these imaging
modalities is injected to the subject and images are acquired as a function of time following the injection. Pharmacokinetic
models analyze these images and extract information about the blood volume, the perfusion of tumours, the ""leakiness"" of
the blood vessels and so on. Some of these measures are used in the clinic to help diagnose which tumour will respond to
which treatment. However, we intend to validate that the values found by the pharmacokinetic models are truly
representative of the tumour micro-environment, as we have reasons to believe that although these values are influenced by
the micro-environment, the models and the acquisition protocols could be improved to provide more physiologically
meaningful values.
We thus propose a series of experiments on a controlled system that will also be simulated using fluid dynamics theory.
This will serve as a benchmark onto which the measures will be calibrated. We will then optimize the data acquisition
protocol of MRI in order to best match the results in the control system. Then, we will combine the models used in MRI and
in PET such that the quality of the information obtained by both imaging modalities one after the other will both be improved.

the analysis of these novel data.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171714&lang=en

We have previously shown that esophageal cancer in Iran has a strong hereditary component although the genes responsible for this are not known. In collaboration with the Center for Digestive Disease in Iran, and with the support of the CIHR, we have created the largest DNA bank in the world for esophageal cancer. We have DNA and clinical information on 700 cases of esophageal cancer and 1500 unaffected ethnic-matched controls. We will use modern technology to do a genome-wide search to identify genes. We will use the Illumina Human610 beadchip to study 500 cases and 500 controls. SNP genotyping data on these samples will be analyzed for comparing SNP frequencies as well as copy number variant (CNV) identification in cases and controls. We will also determine the run of homozygosities (ROH) using SNP genotyping data and determine regions of ROH which are significantly more frequent in cases. We will then validate identified SNPs and CNVs in another set of 400 cases and 800 controls. Finally we will directly sequence the regions identified by associated SNPs, CNVs and ROHs to determine deleterious alleles predispose to esophageal cancer. We expect that this approach will allow us to identify the gene or genes responsible for the hereditary basis of esophageal cancer in Iran. However, bloodwork does have drawbacks, and many patients who are not diagnosed with heart attacks still have elevated troponin levels.  These patients are often cared for in hospital areas other than Cardiology.  This is a diverse group of patients, including those with a traditional heart attack, but who have other significant health problems (such as a terminal cancer or severe dementia which interfere with standard treatments).  Others have a heart attack after an operation.  An elevation in troponin can also be due to another stress (such as severe infection, blood clot in the lung, dangerously high or low blood pressure, anemia or trauma).  Furthermore, patients with severe kidney disease can have elevated troponins.  As a whole, this diverse group of patients has not been well studied, and optimal treatment is not clear.  We plan to study all patients with elevated troponin levels who have been admitted to hospital areas other than cardiac wards.  We will determine the clinical features, investigations, treatment received, and outcomes of these patients.  We want to compare these patients to those with traditional heart attacks who are admitted to cardiology wards.  We believe that patients admitted to other services have more medical conditions, and will have less consistency of care in terms of tests and treatments.  We plan to identify patients who will benefit from conventional heart attack therapies, and also those patients where these therapies may cause harm, in order to improve the overall care of all patients with elevated troponin levels. There are two main types of this disease: type-1 and type-2 diabetes. The prevalence of diabetes is growing rapidly. Globally, the number of adults affected with diabetes is estimated to increase from 135 million in 1995 to 300 million by 2025. Patients with diabetes are at increased risk for heart and blood vessel diseases. Heart and vessel diseases are the leading cause of diabetes-related death. Diabetes can directly damage heart and cause the heart not working properly, a condition called diabetic cardiomyopathy. Diabetic cardiomyopathy occurs independently of other heart disorders such as heart vessel disease and high blood pressure. However, how diabetes causes diabetic cardiomyopathy remains not fully understood. 
Excessive oxidant products have been linked to the onset of diabetic cardiomyopathy. Recent studies have found that damage caused by oxidant products plays a critical role in diabetic cardiomyopathy. Oxidant products are generated by different sources, among which an enzyme called NADPH oxidase has been suggested as a main source in heart muscle cells. A protein called Rac1 is an important subunit of this enzyme and is required for this enzyme's activation. However, the role of Rac1 in diabetic cardiomyopathy has not been fully elucidated. Thus, the present study is aimed to understand if Rac1 plays a role in development of diabetic cardiomyopathy and how Rac1 causes this heart disorder. In the United States alone, close to 300,000 sports-related concussions are reported annually, though the actual number of sustained concussions is likely much higher when unreported and undiagnosed incidences are factored in (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 1997). There has been an increasing amount of research dedicated to investigating the effects of concussions ""or mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI)- including work conducted in our laboratories. 171818,Approaches to understand the regulation of microtubules and microtubule motor proteins in mitotic spindle assembly and the positioning of intracellular structures.,Srayko  Martin A,"Srayko, Martin A",University of Alberta,Alberta,Canada,200809,300000.0,CIHR New Investigator,Salary Programs,Biomedical,Genetics,Cytoskeleton; Microscopy; Microtubules; Molecular Genetics; Motor Proteins; Spindle Assembly,"A single cell division can herald the beginning of life or portend the development of a devastating disease such as cancer. With each division, all animal cells must partition genetic material correctly into the future daughter cells. To do this, the cell first replicates its genetic material and then builds a complex 3D structure to physically separate the duplicated genetic material. This structure is called the mitotic spindle and it is largely composed of long rigid tube-like polymers termed microtubules. In addition to forming the mitotic spindle, microtubules give cells their shape, they help cells move, and they provide a scaffold for the transport of proteins to and from the outer reaches of the cell. How does a simple polymer provide all of these functions within a cell? The simple answer is that the cell contains many proteins that serve as cellular architects, regulating when and where microtubules form. In ways that we do not understand, the microtubule regulators work together to coordinate the assembly and disassembly of microtubules at specific intracellular locations in a timely manner.  In order to better understand the regulation of microtubules in the cell, we are using molecular genetics to identify proteins required for microtubule-based processes such as mitotic spindle assembly. With specialized microscopy assays, we can further characterize the role of the regulatory proteins by determining if they instruct microtubules to grow, shrink, or move. For example, one molecular pathway we are studying is implicated in controlling the stability of microtubules in the mitotic spindle, and another project focuses on understanding how the mitotic spindle is positioned by nano-scale motors that pull on microtubules. Knowledge gained from these studies will help us understand how cells control microtubules during cell division. It could also provide new approaches to interfere with microtubule function as a way to halt renegade cell division in cancer.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171818&lang=en

Understanding how the healthy brain develops is important to understand the consequences when something goes wrong.

While many children develop normally, there are others who suffer from cognitive, neurological, and behavioural problems. Some children have permanent structural brain damage because of the consumption of alcohol by the mother during pregnancy, leading to a broad condition known as fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). Children with FASD often have motor delays, and deficits in attention, learning and memory, executive functioning, mathematics, and language. Quantitative MRI may identify regions of brain abnormality that are not detected with conventional clinical MRI. Differences in the severity and location of brain changes may explain the range of cognitive deficits seen amongst FASD children. Knowledge of the responsible brain regions could lead to improved therapies and individual-based treatment strategies since all patients may not show the same structural abnormalities.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=171857&lang=en

Hypoxic cells therefore represents a valid target and their eradication would improve the response and cure rate of radiotherapy and therefore could have huge significance for the management of cancer.

The proposed research adopts a previously untried strategy whereby the repair of radiation-induced DNA damage is inhibited selectively in hypoxic cells thereby reducing their resistance to radiotherapy.

This strategy will be accomplished by linking inhibitors of DNA repair with hypoxia activating moieties based on established 'trigger' chemistry. The drug will be inactive in oxygenated cells, but in hypoxic cells the drug will release an active inhibitor of DNA repair. Our goal is to develop a multi-component therapeutic strategy that will restore cognitive function by halting the toxicity of amyloid-beta using novel and effective methods including immunotherapy combined with non-invasive MRI-guided focused ultrasound delivery, scyllo-inositol, and rescuing cholinergic neurons by delivering NGF to specific areas of the brain. We hypothesize that limiting the toxicity of amyloid-beta will enhance the regenerative potential of cholinergic neurons in presence of NGF. In mouse models of Alzheimer's disease, this combined treatment is expected to restore axonal networks leading to the recovery of behavioral functions.

disease. We argue that we need to understand how genes are expressed  
in the endothelial cells of the body and how these pathways become  
abnormal in disease. What makes an endothelial gene turn off in  
diseased human blood vessels? Classically the nucleus has been viewed  
as the key regulator of gene expression. Yet all cells have the same  
DNA. Why do endothelial cells express only certain genes in healthy  
tissue? In disease many of these genes turn off. Why does the nucleus  
get affected? These processes are chromosome-based or chromatin-based,  
and are also called epigenetic processes. What we inherit from our  
parents, or what one cell passes on two cells when it divides,  
represents the ""nature"" side of the equation. These processes are  
influenced by the environment. This represents the ""nurture"" side of  
the equation. Whatever our cells sense in their external world  
interacts with genetic material in the nucleus to influence gene  
expression. Epigenetics is broadly defined as the mechanisms that  
control gene expression that do not involve the DNA sequence per se.  
We are among the first to study these concepts in the cardiovascular  
sciences. We believe that the principles we uncover in endothelial  
cells will teach us about blood vessels gene regulation in general.

In humans, coxsackie B viruses (CBV) are the most frequent cause of viral induced myocarditis.  It is estimated that 30% of new DCM cases in North America are the result of coxsackievirus infection. After viral infection, disease resistant individuals develop a short-lived disease while in other disease susceptible individuals the disease progresses to a chronic, autoimmune disease.  The objective of our project is to determine how disease progresses from the short-lived disease to the chronic disease.  As mice develop a similar disease to humans after CBV infection, we will be using disease resistant and disease susceptible mice to determine which cellular components are involved in causing long-term myocarditis. Using a variety of mice that are missing a single component of their immune system, we can determine which immune components are important in disease initiation. We will infect these mice with CBV and monitor them for development of chronic myocarditis.  If a mouse deficient of a certain component of their immune system doesn't develop the chronic disease after CBV infection, we will know that this component is likely involved in the progression from a short lived disease into a chronic disease. Alternatively, we will treat the mice with environmental agents that stimulate the immune system at the same time as CBV infection.  If adding these agents causes an increase in chronic disease, we will have identified important information with regard to how disease advances. In turn, these findings would translate into novel therapeutic approaches towards disease prevention.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172008&lang=en

172064,High-resolution measurements of mitotic spindle dynamics during the cell cycle,Kilfoil  Maria L,"Kilfoil, Maria L; Vogel, Jackie",McGill University,Qu&eacute;bec,Canada,200809,253596.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Biomedical,Genetics,Automated Phenotyping; Cell Biology; Cell Division; Cytoskeleton; Experimental Biophysics; Microscopy And Image Analysis,"Mitosis is the last stage of the division of a mother cell into two daughter cells. Early in mitosis, each duplicated chromosome becomes attached to microtubules, dynamic fibers that originate at opposite poles of the spindle. Next, the spindle increases in length while the microtubules attached to the chromosomes shorten, separating the chromosome pairs into two while moving them from the spindle center towards one of the two poles. In some cells, such as precursors to eggs and stem cells, division results in daughter cells that are unequal in size and have very different fates. In this case, the spindle must be asymmetrically positioned within the mother for the cleavage of the mother cell into unequal daughter cells. While the process of asymmetric cell division is apparently simple and elegant, we know little about how it occurs. How does the spindle find its proper position in the cell? How is this process timed such that the spindle is properly positioned after chromosomes are attached to microtubules, but before cleavage begins? With what landmarks in the cell and through what signaling does the spindle communicate during this process? Failure to properly coordinate spindle assembly with its translocation and with the onset of chromosome segregation can result in a cell with an abnormal number of chromosomes, a cause of cancer and birth defects. We propose to study this in budding yeast, simple asymmetrically dividing cell. We will also study how the cell organizes its mass in such a way that cell size is constant from one generation to the next. Budding yeast as a model system is manageable for extracting fine detail and for perturbing genetically, has a convenient length of life cycle and even happens to be a convenient geometry, but still shares all of the same force generators and cell architecture that our cells have. Our studies will increase our understanding of general principles of cell division and the causes of abnormal chromosome number in cells.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172064&lang=en

Radiation-induced tumors and other toxic radiation effects have been reported to occur to a different extent in males and females. Mechanisms of these differences remain elusive. The DNA content of each cell in a given higher organism is identical: our liver and brain cells contain the same DNA, but they are very different in their shapes and functions. This is due to the existence of different patterns in reading and translation of genes for the type of cells in question, referred to as 'gene expression'. This is the domain of the emerging science of epigenetics  (literally, 'beyond genetics'). Remarkable features of epigenetic changes include simple chemical modifications of the 'C' base in DNA by attachment or removal of methyl (-CH3) groups. Highly methylated regions of DNA are turned off or silenced - a kind of cellular dimmer switch.  Most amazing and contrary to popular opinion that DNA sequences determine everything, epigenetic changes can extend beyond cell division to reproduction. Although epigenetic changes are inheritable, they are reversible. A lot still has to be learned about the role of epigenetic changes in living cells and organisms and their interactions with the environment. In my laboratory, we have found that males and females respond to radiation differently due to distinct epigenetic changes in DNA methylation. These changes may lead to different levels of radiation toxicity. Currently, we would like to understand (i) which epigenetic changes occur in males and females; (ii) why epigenetic changes in males and females are different; (iii) which cellular processes they affect. Importantly, unchecked cell proliferation may cause increased number of cells, or tumors, that can turn into cancer. Controlling cell proliferation requires that cells communicate with each other by secreting different types of growth factors into the external side of these cells.  Some of these growth factors instruct cells to proliferate, while others stop cells form dividing. The TGF-ßs are members of a family of secreted growth factors that prevent many normal cell types from proliferating.   However, cells may change to become resistant to anti-proliferative effect of TGFß. This change can potentially start small tumors.  At later stages of tumor development, TGF-ß can produce other effects on these cells, such as changes in cell shape and promotion of cell movement. These TGFß-effects may help the tumors to be metastatic because cancer cells can spread into the blood stream.  Once blood bourn cancer cells can spread into other parts of the body. In general, cancer may arise from either an increase in the amount or activity of cellular factors that promote cell proliferation and enhance the ability of cells to migrate.  These cellular factors are referred to as proto-oncogenes.  Tumors can also result from a decrease in the amount or function of cellular factors that prevent cell proliferation and resist cell movement.  These types of factors are called tumor suppressors. The overall goal of this research proposal is to understand which and how changes in proto-oncogenes or tumor suppressors affect the ability of cells to respond to TGF-ß. It has been hypothesized that certain ""protective"" HLA molecules mediate a particularly strong and effective immune response that selects for escape mutations that compromise the virus' ability to replicate. 172256,New concept of hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction: Conducted response via connexin 40,Kuebler  Wolfgang M,"Kuebler, Wolfgang M",Unity Health Toronto,Ontario,Canada,200809,333308.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Biomedical,Circulatory and Respiratory Health,Conducted Response; Endothelial Cells; Endotoxemia; Gap Junctions; Hypoxic Pulmonary Vasoconstriction; Intravital Microscopy,"In the lung, blood vessels react to hypoxia with a rapid and sustained contraction termed hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (HPV). HPV redistributes blood flow from areas which are poorly aerated to intact lung regions with better ventilation. In this way, sufficient blood oxygenation is maintained even when 50% of lung tissue no longer contribute to gas exchange.
Lung inflammation or sepsis, but also commonly used anesthetics attenuate HPV and may thus impair blood oxygenation. A perpetuated HPV may also be detrimental in generalized hypoxia e.g. at high altitude, since contraction of all resistance vessels will increase blood pressure in the lung and ultimately cause lung edema and/or right heart failure.
Despite its relevance, the involved signaling mechanisms and the exact sites of oxygen sensing and vasoconstriction are incompletely understood. We have established innovative imaging methods which allow for the direct visualization of blood vessels and blood oxygenation in the intact lung. We can show that the primary site of gas exchange is at the level of the smallest blood vessels, the capillaries, while vasoconstriction is confined to upstream arterioles. We thus postulate a signal conduction mechanism which must propagate the hypoxic signal from the capillaries to the arterioles and suggest a critical role for the molecule connexin 40 (Cx40) which facilitates rapid signal conduction by electric coupling of adjoining cells. Our proposed experiments aim to (i) characterize the role of Cx40 in HPV, (ii) identify the cellular mechanisms which underlie the signal conduction from capillaries to arterioles, and (iii) test the relevance of this concept for clinical conditions in which HPV is impaired or perpetuated. The results of this project will change our understanding of one of the basic mechanisms of vascular regulation, and will provide the basis for new therapeutic strategies in the treatment of diseases in which lung vascular tone is dysregulated.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172256&lang=en

This genetic test has the ability to predict whether an individual will develop HD in their lifetime and thus, have the ability to pass the disease onto their children.  Some individuals who undergo predictive testing receive an unusual test result which differs from a positive or negative result.  This result is called an intermediate allele(IA). Individuals with an IA will never develop HD but there remains a risk that their children or grandchildren could develop the disease.  

In the literature there remains many gaps in knowledge regarding IAs for HD. In particular, the current International Predictive Testing Guidelines do not address the possibility of this result, nor are the complexities surrounding this result acknowledged.  This study will not only address these gaps, but will inform the development of clinical standards of care for communicating IA results during predictive testing.  

The specific objectives of this study are to determine the prevalence of IAs in a North American general population; determine quantified risk estimates for the likelihood than an individual with an IA will have a child who will develop the disease; and lastly, describe the psychological and social implications and impact of receiving an IA result.  

This study will represent the largest empirical study on HD IAs to date. Collectively, the three objectives of this unique, multidisciplinary study will provide the foundation on which to base the development of clinical standards and practice recommendations for IA predictive test results.  These standards will help ensure that this subset of patients receive appropriate information, support, education, and counselling throughout their predictive testing process.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172289&lang=en

172386,"Characterization of a novel, caspase-8 dependent survival pathway in inflammatory neutrophils",Marshall  John C,"Marshall, John C",Unity Health Toronto,Ontario,Canada,200809,501135.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Biomedical,Infection and Immunity,Apoptosis; Cell Signaling; Critical Illness; Innate Immunity; Neutrophils; Sepsis,"White blood cells known as neutrophils form the body's first line of defense against infection.  They release a potent array of substances that kill invading bacteria, and so are essential to surviving a life-threatening infection.  But these same substances can cause unwanted damage to healthy host tissues.  Tissue injury by neutrophils, for example, contributes to a condition known as sepsis in critically ill patients in an ICU, and to joint injury in patients with arthritis. In health, the potential for injury is minimized because of the neutrophil lives for only a very brief period, before dying a death by cellular suicide through a process known as apoptosis.  During inflammation, the neutrophil's ability to undergo apoptosis is inhibited, with the result that its capacity for both host defense and tissue injury is enhanced.  We have found that neutrophil survival is dependent on changes to the structure of an enzyme called caspase-8 that initiates the process of apoptosis.  The addition of a phosphate molecule to an amino acid in capase-8 (a process called phosphorylation) blocks its activity.  In the studies proposed here, we will first determine whether phosphorylated caspase-8 is needed to activate a protein known as PI3 kinase, which regulates the survival program in the neutrophil.   We will define the role in neutrophil survival of a new survival gene that we have recently identified and called ILIP-1 (Interleukin-1-Induced Protein-1).  These processes - caspase-8 phosphorylation, PI3 kinase activation, and expression of ILIP-1 - comprise an integrated complex that we have termed the 'casapase-8 survivalsome'.  Finally, we will determine whether modulation of the survivalsome in neutrophils from critically ill patients with sepsis can restore the normal expression of apoptosis.  Together the studies will provide the insights necessary to develop new treatments for life-threatening inflammation that are based on preventing the persistence of inflammation.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172386&lang=en

As network gatekeepers, GABAergic inhibitory interneurons control all stages of information processing by principal neurons, from signal integration to generating spikes and synchronized network oscillations. To perform these precise operations, inhibitory interneurons must be tightly organized in functional ensembles. In the hippocampus, the brain structure involved in learning and memory, a specific population of inhibitory interneurons selectively innervates other GABAergic cells, and may provide the cellular basis for such higher-level control of network computations. However, the physiological properties and the role of these cells in the local circuit dialogue remain unknown. We propose that the specific physiological organization of these interneuron-specific interneurons (ISIs) allows them to efficiently integrate multiple cortical and subcortical inputs and to act as a fine-tuning device sculpting the inhibition received by principal cells. We will use a combination of whole-cell patch-clamp electrophysiology, two-photon microscopy, and pharmacology in acute slices of mouse hippocampus to investigate: (1) how ISIs integrate signals and produce spikes; (2) how their signal integration is affected by the activation of subcortical inputs; (3) how connections between inhibitory interneurons are modified by changes in activity; and (4) how the inhibitory control of local circuit inhibition directs the network activity.
This investigation should provide essential information about the functional organization of inhibitory interneurons specialized to control network inhibition. This disease is common in the newborn period because of two factors: 1) a failure of the normal dilation of blood vessels in the lung at birth that allows oxygen to enter the blood, and 2) rapid development of thickening of the walls of blood vessels (known as remodeling), which blocks the normal passage of blood through the lung and prevents vessels from properly relaxing.  The treatments we currently have available to treat babies with pulmonary hypertension often do not work, do not improve remodeling of blood vessels and have not been shown to decrease death or to improve outcome in the long term.  The overall goal of my research is to develop more effective treatments for the prevention and treatment of pulmonary hypertension in newborns.  To facilitate this goal, my laboratory has developed two newborn rat models of chronic pulmonary hypertension, which have many similarities to human newborns that do not respond to conventional treatments.  Published and preliminary work from my laboratory indicates that the induction of high carbon dioxide levels in the blood (hypercapnia) can prevent lung injury and improve pulmonary hypertension in newborn rats.  The aims of our proposed work are to further define the ""dose"" of hypercapnia that is required to effectively treat pulmonary hypertension, to better understand how hypercapnia works, to ascertain its effects on lung development and to see whether its beneficial effects will last into adult life.  This work will provide new insights with a high potential for clinical translation.  Hypercapnia has great potential as an effective and enticingly simple therapeutic approach to an otherwise intractable problem.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172491&lang=en

From a health perspective, it is critical to elucidate these mechanisms because impairments in feelings of familiarity represent a clinical feature of various neurological diseases, including Alzheimer's disease, stroke, and epilepsy. Here, we plan to shed light on the brain mechanisms that cause impairments in feelings of familiarity in epilepsy. Revealing the molecular mechanisms between the battle of the virus and host is vital in our fight against clinically relevant viruses. One mechanism that some viruses use is through an IRES. In our cells, molecular machines, called ribosomes, translate our genes into proteins, but some viruses, such as hepatitis C virus and poliovirus, possess an IRES to hijack the ribosome to preferentially express their viral proteins. We need a better understanding of these mechanisms in order to fight viral infections.
      This proposal will gain insight into these viral IRESs by elucidating the mechanisms by which a unique IRES, found within an insect virus called the cricket paralysis virus (CrPV), can hijack the ribosome. Because the CrPV IRES directly recruits ribosomes without any factors, it provides a simple and powerful model to study IRES functions and will lay the foundation for studying more complex IRESs. Our previous work was seminal in delineating important CrPV IRES functions. Building on this work, we aim: 1) to use innovative techniques to map the specific IRES elements that interact with the ribosome, 2) to determine how the CrPV disrupt cellular functions that leads to IRES activity in Drosophila (fruit fly) cells, and 3) to elucidate the host antiviral responses in Drosophila cells, which have not been fully investigated. Because molecular signals are often conserved, the study of Drosophila antiviral responses is relevant in revealing fundamental virus host interactions in humans. For example, when listening to a conversation, hearing declines might cause older adults to mishear individual words more often than younger adults. Alternatively, cognitive declines may make it more difficult for older adults to integrate information coming from different conversationalists, leading to misinterpretation of what was said. Our research program is designed to determine the relative contribution of these two kinds of declines to spoken language comprehension so that appropriate steps can be taken to improve language comprehension in older adults (e.g., assistive listening devices for hearing declines; medication and/or therapies for cognitive declines). To date, we have been able to show that declines in hearing abilities rather than declines in cognitive abilities are responsible for most of the comprehension difficulties experienced by healthy older adults when they are listening to sentences, lectures, or simple two-person conversations. As we move, the brain integrates multiple sensory signals to compute estimates of our self-motion. However, this poses a challenge because the way that sensory signals must be combined and interpreted depends on the conditions (context) in which they are sensed. One important contextual influence is gravity. Gravity provides a world-fixed reference (i.e., which way is up/down) for interpreting our motion. To navigate during locomotion or maintain upright posture we rely on information about our motion with respect to this fixed spatial reference. However, because each of our sensors is attached to different body parts, no one sensor provides this information. For example, our vestibular sensors (semicircular canals and otoliths) signal head movement along axes fixed in the head. Thus, when running to catch a ball, the same movement in space (e.g., forward motion) is sensed by one combination of sensors when the head is upright and a different set when the head is tilted backward to look up at the ball. To maintain balance as we run, we must also know our tilt relative to gravity. This too requires combining sensory signals in a head-orientation-dependent way. Gravity thus serves as a fundamental contextual cue for interpreting the motion our sensors encode. The goal of this work is to investigate the contextual role of gravity on the integration of multisensory (vestibular, visual) signals in the brainstem and cerebellum. By better understanding how the brain computes spatial motion estimates that are essential for tasks such as navigation and postural control, it is hoped that this research will lead to improved rehabilitative strategies to counteract spatial disorientation, balance and dizziness disorders, debilitating problems that are particularly common in the elderly.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172579&lang=en
172595,Novel Therapeutic Strategies For Obstructive Bladder Disease,Bagli  Darius J,"Bagli, Darius J",Hospital for Sick Children (Toronto),Ontario,Canada,200809,440244.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Biomedical,"Human Development, Child and Youth Health",Bladder Obstruction; Distension Hypoxia; Egfr; Fibroproliferation; Iressa; Mtor; Rapamycin; Smooth Muscle,"Our research goal is to find new drug treatments for bladder obstruction. Obstruction creates multiple health problems 
including incontinence, recurrent urine infection, and kidney damage, resulting in nearly $30 billion in annual health care 
costs. Obstruction leads to pressure and distension injury, which is also accompanied by decreased oxygen delivery to the 
bladder muscle (hypoxia). The bladder muscle wall becomes thickened and fibrotic and eventually bladder function fails. We 
have developed an organ model which permits study of the rat bladder in culture. This organ culture system has shown that distension and hypoxia stimuli trigger specific enzymatic and molecular changes which drive smooth muscle overgrowth. Using computer analysis of the genes we have identified to date, expressed by the distended rat organ and by stretched human bladder muscle cells, we have found that 
the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) and the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) pathways may regulate bladder obstruction responses. We observe that the mTOR inhibitor drug rapamycin, is able to block growth of stretched cells and hypoxic cells. We have also reported that EGFR regulates BMSC growth triggered my stretching the organ in culture, and in cultured hypoxic BSMC. Therefore, we are testing the idea that hypoxia regulates muscle responses to 
distension using shared biological pathways.  This project will exploit these two stimuli in our organ system to study 3 areas: 
1. How hypoxia modifies distension responses in the bladder tissue using the mTOR & EGFR pathways, 2. How hypoxia modifies function of the component parts of the mTOR pathway in response to distension, and 3. Assessing rapamycin and the EGFR inhibitor Iressa to treat bladder damage in a live animal model of chronic bladder obstruction. These studies will provide significant new understanding and treatment directions for bladder obstruction.",4 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172595&lang=en

We will determine if inhibiting MMP-2 will protect the cells and the hearts from cell injury and death resulting from oxidative stress. When not treated at an early stage of disease progression, melanoma patients often have a poor survival outcome, since metastatic melanoma is very aggressive. It is generally believed that cancer is caused when individual cells develop a series of changes in their DNA or genetic material. These changes allow them to escape normal growth restrictions. 

Our main goal is to understand how melanoma forms in people. We began this project by using mice to model the genetics of skin pigmentation. We focused on three genes that we found darkened the mouse skin when mutated: GNAQ, GNA11 and NF1. We have since identified a mutation in GNAQ in 46% of uveal melanomas, a cancer of the pigment cells in the uveal tract of the eye. GNAQ is the first oncogene identified in this type of cancer and suggests novel therapeutic strategies for its treatment. 172623,Processing of proIAPP: Role in islet amyloid formation,Verchere  Bruce C,"Verchere, Bruce C",BC Children's Hospital Research Institute,British Columbia,Canada,200809,621784.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Biomedical,"Nutrition, Metabolism and Diabetes",Amylin; Amyloid; Beta Cell; Cell Biology; Histology; Iapp,"Many people with type 2 diabetes must take insulin by injection because of the loss of insulin-producing cells, called islet beta cells, in their pancreas. It is thought that this loss of islet beta cells is due islet amyloid, a toxic accumulation of protein.

In order to better understand why protein builds up in people with type 2 diabetes, we propose to study the forms of a protein hormone called pro-islet amyloid polypeptide (proIAPP).

ProIAPP is made within the insulin-producing islet beta cells. When it is cut by enzymes, it becomes a smaller protein hormone called islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP). Islet amyloid forms when, for unknown reasons, IAPP forms aggregates that kill the islet beta cells.

We believe that in type 2 diabetes, the process through which proIAPP is cut to form IAPP is defective, leading to an accumulation of incompletely cut forms of proIAPP, that then aggregate to form amyloid. 

We will study the forms of proIAPP in the blood of persons with type 2 diabetes and in mice that make excessive amounts of the protein hormone. Through this research, we hope to understand why islet amyloid occurs in people with type 2 diabetes. Our goal is to contribute to developing new therapies that may prevent this protein buildup and the resulting destruction of the pancreas' insulin producing cells.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172623&lang=en

The acquisition of basic motor skills enables and motivates engagement in activities for life. This program of research is designed to fill a knowledge gap about the action-observation process in people with Down syndrome. The specific aim is to study how these people observe and attend to actions in others in order to facilitate the learning of physical skills. Surprisingly very little is know about how to effectively teach people with Down syndrome motor skills and the processes engaged during observation and motor learning. These individuals appear to learn well from demonstrations, in comparison to mental age matched controls, yet there is evidence from brain imaging studies that this process is different to typically developing individuals, not involving activation of motor-areas of the brain. Further, no one has systematically studied what information drives this observational learning process. During actual movement, there is evidence that people with Down syndrome have difficulties predicting the future effects of their action, in terms of how an action looks and feels. We do not know whether this difficulty extends to the observation process and hence this research will help answer this question through studies requiring the prediction of movement effects when watching others. We will use behavioural methods to study these questions, involving the measurement of responses to demonstrated actions, both in the short term and long-term learning of novel actions. We will also develop our own phenotypic assay to assist in the validation of our sequencing-based approach. With our proposed project, we can combine basic science and clinical information to provide a more efficient and more cost-effective screening assay. In addition, this proposal should also lead to significant improvements in monitoring HIV. About 30 to 40% of the children who may be identified through screening present with mild bilateral or unilateral hearing loss (one ear).   Prior to screening, the majority of these children were not identified until 4 to 6 years of age.  While studies have shown that late-identified hearing loss affects these children's behavior and abilities in school, the impact of hearing loss when it is identified very early in life is less clear. This study will follow a group of early identified children over several years to identify the difficulties they are experiencing compared to a group of children with normal hearing. One such security mechanism is shutting down genes, also known as gene silencing. Gene silencing is at the heart of development and specialization. It has thus recently been widely used to study human and model organisms' genetics and development, and to create transgenic plants developing resistance to viruses. Increasing evidences suggest that diseases such as cancer are the result of multiple gene deregulations. A normal cellular reaction in front of such deregulations is shutting down these genes.  However, in the case of cancer for unknown reasons, the cell is unable to do so and tumors develop and progress. We need to understanding better gene silencing mechanisms if we wish to discover why the cell cannot defends itself against cancer, or if we want to intervene efficiently in gene silencing to fight cancer. Gene silencing is based on a class of ribonucleic acids called microRNAs. One of the aims of this research proposal is to study the molecular basis of these microRNAs, and in particular the binding mechanism by which they bind the messenger RNAs of targeted genes. Predicting accurately the targeted genes of microRNAs is among the most important unresolved questions of gene silencing at this moment. Dr. Major proposes the application of an RNA computer-modeling framework he developed over the last 20 years to obtain high-resolution 3-D structures of microRNAs as well as of their targeted messenger RNAs. These 3-D structures will help him get insights into how and where microRNAs bind their targets, and prepare biological assays to confirm these insights.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172674&lang=en
172688,The concurrent use of medications with opposing actions: the prevalence and impact of prescribing both anticholinergics and cholinesterase inhibitors to people with dementia,Gill  Sudeep S,"Gill, Sudeep S","Queen's University (Kingston, Ontario)",Ontario,Canada,200809,124555.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Clinical,Aging,Administrative Health Care Databases; Adverse Drug Events; Clinical Pharmacology; Geriatrics; Nested Case-Control Study; Pharmacoepidemiology,"A wide variety of medications possess anticholinergic properties, meaning they block a chemical called acetylcholine in the body. The anticholinergic effects of these drugs can be especially concerning in older adults for several reasons. First, they can lead to acute urinary retention (the sudden, painful inability to void). Second, anticholinergic drugs can also interfere with memory and thinking, which is especially dangerous for older people with dementia. In fact, another group of drugs called the cholinesterase inhibitors, which are used to treat dementia, essentially have the opposite effect of anticholinergic drugs. Despite their opposing actions, anticholinergics and cholinesterase inhibitors are sometimes prescribed together. This practice may provoke serious adverse effects such as acute urinary retention and worsening confusion. We will find out how commonly these drugs with opposing actions are prescribed together, and whether this prescribing practice leads to safety problems in frail older adults with dementia. If we find evidence of harm, a policy to help alert physicians to the hazards of co-prescribing these drugs may help to limit this problem.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172688&lang=en

If one considers a gene as though it were a sentence such as THE CAT ATE THE FAT FAT RAT, typical mutations would pose as spelling errors.  For instance THE GAT ATE THE FAT FAT RAT.  This mutation would be the same in all individuals in the family, all with the same symptoms.  However, in repeat-associated diseases the mutation would be THE CAT ATE THE FAT FAT FAT FAT FAT RAT, and their children would inherit a further mutation; THE CAT ATE THE FAT FAT FAT FAT FAT FAT FAT FAT RAT and have more severe disease than their parents.  These mutations also continue through the life of the patient; progressively making symptoms worse.  My research focuses on understanding this form of mutation with the long-term goal of being able to prevent or treat affected families.  Being able to arrest or reverse this repeat mutation (reducing or preventing the expansion of the number of ""FAT"" repeat units) presents a therapeutic pathway to reduce disease severity; a pathway whose elucidation will be facilitated by understanding of the mutation process. 

To understand this mutation we will focus on: 1) unusual DNA structures that form at the repeating units that are thought to be involved in the mutation; 2) mistakes during the process of DNA replication, which duplicates the DNA when making a new cell: and 3) DNA repair which repairs broken DNA and unusual DNA structures.  Mistakes during replication and repair are thought to cause the mutation of repeats in these diseases.  Our studies will decipher the mechanisms of this disease-causing mutation and will reveal candidate targets for research avenues aimed at therapeutic treatment by arresting or reversing the expansion mutations (FAT FAT FAT FAT FAT RAT.......down to......FAT FAT R",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172704&lang=en

172793,Deciphering the cis-regulatory code of Drosophila mRNA regulation using integrative computational and biochemical genomic analyses.,Morris  Quaid D,"Morris, Quaid D",University of Toronto,Ontario,Canada,200809,556685.0,Operating Grant,Operating Grants,Biomedical,Genetics,Computational Biology; Machine Learning; Mrna Processing; Pattern Recognition; Protein Binding Microarrays; Rna-Binding Proteins,"The messages from our genome that direct cellular function are encoded in RNA.  These messages (called mRNA) not only contain instructions on how to build a specific protein but also instructions on where, when, and how many copies of that protein to build.  Though we already know the genetic code that describes how to translate the RNA message into its associated protein product, we still do not know how to read the other instructions, those that regulate the production of the protein, encoded in the mRNA.

Deciphering the RNA regulation code is important.  Many inherited diseases appear to be caused by genetic mutations in RNA regulatory instructions.  Furthermore, knowing the RNA regulation code may provide us with new strategies for treating disease by targeting aspects of mRNA regulation.

We propose to decipher this regulation code in two steps.  First, we will learn the ""words"" of the code by analyzing the binding preferences of the regulatory proteins that bind to mRNA.  Then, we will decipher the ""grammar"" of the code by using computer algorithms that learn to predict the localization and stability of an mRNA based on the sequence of code words it contains.  We will validate our predictions by manipulating what we believe to be the regulatory instructions in particular mRNAs, and ensure that our predictions on how the regulation changes match reality.

We will carry out this research in fruit flies (Drosophila) because the regulatory code is likely to be similar between fruit flies and human, but there is readily available data on mRNA regulation in fruit flies that is unavailable in humans.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172793&lang=en
172797,"The effects of C-type natriuretic peptide and its receptors on sinoatrial node function, heart rate regulation and arrhythmogenesis",Rose  Robert A,"Rose, Robert A",Dalhousie University (Nova Scotia),Nova Scotia,Canada,200809,300000.0,CIHR New Investigator,Salary Programs,Biomedical,Circulatory and Respiratory Health,Arrhythmias; Electrophysiology; Heart Rate; Natriuretic Peptide; Sinoatrial Node; Transgenics,"Natriuretic peptides are a family of related hormones produced in the heart that are very important in the context of normal heart function and heart disease. Heart rate (the number of times the heart beats per minute) regulates the delivery of blood to all regions of the body and is determined by specialized 'pacemaker' cells in a region of the heart called the sinoatrial node. My lab is interested in how natriuretic peptides regulate the specialized sinoatrial node region of the heart. Since we began studying this topic we have found that one kind of natriuretic peptide, called CNP, can potently reduce heart rate by binding to a specific receptor called the natriuretic peptide C receptor (or NPR-C). Originally, scientists thought this NPR-C receptor had no function, but our work is helping to change this idea. Many more experiments are necessary to understand how CNP and the NPR-C receptor affect heart rate and the sinoatrial node. CNP also binds to a second kind of receptor called NPR-B. Very little is known about the role of the NPR-B receptor in the sinoatrial node; therefore, we are also studying this receptor so that we may ultimately understand how both NPR-C and NPR-B contribute to heart rate regulation by CNP. This work is important because heart failure is characterized by the occurrence of life threatening arrhythmias, some of which are associated with dysfunction of the sinoatrial node. The body increases its production of natriuretic peptides in heart disease because these peptides help prevent heart failure from worsening over time. We hypothesize that natriuretic peptides will be effective in treating or preventing arrhythmias during heart failure in people and believe our work will help lead to significant improvements in the use and development of synthetic natriuretic peptides for the treatment of people suffering from heart failure, arrhythmias and other forms of heart disease.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=172797&lang=en

Conversely, diseases such as cancer result from aberrant signaling, that results in inappropriate cell growth and migration. In normal tissues, cellular communication is a two-way process, such that different cell types signal back and forth. A striking example involves two types of transmembrane proteins found on the surfaces of distinct cells, termed Eph receptors and ephrins. These proteins contact one another, and by transmitting molecular information into both cell types drive a sorting process, such that Eph receptor- and ephrin-expressing cells segregate into two spatially distinct populations. This type of bidirectional cell signaling is also important in disease tissues, such as cancers, in which the tumour and surrounding stromal cells exchange signals in a reciprocal fashion to support the growth of the tumour. We have developed a novel biochemical technique that allows us, for the first time, to directly analyze bidirectional signaling when different cells types are cultured together, for example cells expressing Eph receptors or ephrins. We will couple this proteomic approach with a functional analysis of proteins required for cell sorting, and use computational and experimental tools to define the network of signaling proteins that allows bidirectional signaling between Eph receptor- and ephrin-expressing cells to mediate cell segregation. I believe that insulin resistance is promoted by elevated numbers of the atherogenic particles that carries cholesterol in the blood (like LDL). Accordingly obese subjects with elevated particle numbers (termed hyperapoB) have higher risk for developing type 2 diabetes than those with normal particle numbers (termed normal apoB).  

Methods: I will recruit 96 obese subjects without diabetes or chronic disease (>45 years, 50%men, 50%postmenopausal women). Subjects with hyperapoB will be compared to subjects with normal apoB and equivalent cholesterol concentrations (48 subjects/ group) at 1) baseline and 2) following 6-months hypocaloric-diet intervention to reduce weight by 10%. Mechanisms examined to explain the differences in insulin sensitivity between the 2 groups will be; rate of dietary fat storage, inflammation in the blood and fat tissue, blood atherogenic particles profile and fat tissue genes that affect metabolism.  

Hypotheses: I hypothesize that compared to subjects with normal apoB, obese subjects with hyperapoB have 1) lower insulin sensitivity at baseline due to a slower rate of fat storage and higher inflammation, 2) greater increase in insulin sensitivity after weight loss due to a greater decrease in atherogenic particles' numbers and inflammation and a greater increase in the rate of fat storage.

In some stroke patients the symptoms from this blocked artery are mild or even transient. There are around half a million stroke patients who present with transient or mild stroke symptoms every year in North America. In the more severe strokes, clot busting drugs are used to unblock the blocked artery. This drug has a rare but serious side effect of bleeding into the brain and so doctors only use this drug when the symptoms are very severe. Tragically many of these mild patients have a second more severe stroke that leaves them disabled. If we can show which patients with mild deficits are at high risk for a second stroke, then we could target new drugs at patients who are at the highest risk.
Mild stroke patients with a blocked blood vessel and damage seen on a brain MRI scan are at high risk for a second stroke. Sadly MRI is not available as an emergency for most of Canada's population. In most centres CT scans are more readily available than MRI. If CT can identify which patients are at risk for a second stroke then many more at risk patients could be identified. In this study we are seeking to show that a CT scan can also predict which patients are at risk for a recurrent stroke. 
Patients with mild or transient deficits presenting within 24 hours of symptom onset to the emergency room will be enrolled in this study. Patients will have both a CT and a MRI scan completed quickly and the results for each test will be compared against how well the patient does. We will show whether a CT can predict which mild or transient events are going to do badly. It will also allow us to see whether CT or MRI is better in predicting who is going to do badly. Under conditions of microbial infection, CD8 T cell responses specific for pathogen-derived MIP peptides are elicited and these antigen-specific cells are primarily responsible for eradicating infection. However, under normal, steady-state conditions, peptides derived from ""self"" proteins are continually degraded as part of the constitutive activity of the proteasome and are presented on the cell surface as the ""self"" MIP repertoire. Likewise, tumor-associated antigens expressed by cancer cells are processed to become part of the cancer MIP repertoire and in doing so represent ideal target antigens for potential immunotherapeutic intervention.  Despite the tremendous potential importance of the cancer MIP repertoire, relatively little is known about its composition or complexity. In the current proposal we intend to catalogue the MIP repertoire present on the surface of ovarian cancer cells. Specifically, we will utilize malignant ascites samples from patients with stage III-IV ovarian cancer as a source of cells for mass spectrometry-based identification of MHC-associated peptides. Malignant ascites removed from ovarian cancer patients via paracentesis, or as part of de-bulking surgery, frequently contains extraordinary numbers of tumor cells (>108) which can be readily purified from any infiltrating immune cells. Two complimentary approaches for peptide purification will be utilized, 1) peptides will be directly eluted from surface MHC using mild acid treatment and 2) peptides will be acid eluted from specific MHC molecules that have been immuno-precipitated from tumor cell lysates. The reasons for cancer recurrence are not fully understood however it has been thought for quite some time that it occurs because there are tumor cells that are able to escape chemotherapy and radiation to remain dormant until an opportune time to regrow.  Some attribute this to the idea that within every tumor lies a small group of tumor initiating cells (TIC) that have not only the ability to escape the challenges of therapy but also to establish new tumor growth.  These so called TIC only constitute about 2-10% of the total tumor and have successfully been isolated from patients because they have a unique signature of cell surface proteins called CD44 and CD49f.  We recently made key observation that the Y-box binding protein-1 (YB-1) increases the abundance of CD44 and CD49f.  Importantly, YB-1 also confers multi-drug resistance and we find it is highly associated with breast cancer recurrence in an analysis of over 4000 cases.  Using a newly developed small molecule against YB-1, we intend to inhibit the expression of the CD44 and CD49f with the idea that this will suppress the growth of TIC and thus the re-establishment of tumors in mice.  In the second part of this project, we will take advantage of a high content screening instrument that will allow us to evaluate the potential for off patent drugs to be used to inhibit the growth of TIC.  In a preliminary screen, we have identified 27 drugs that could potentially block the growth of TIC however more work is needed to validate these findings. Microflora studies in infants have either lacked information on antibiotic use or have been conducted soon after birth, at a time when antibiotic use, especially broad-spectrum antibiotic, is limited. Antibiotic use in the infant will be evaluated against other factors which influence microbiota, such as mode of delivery and type of infant feeding. surroundings. Whether the bacteria that live in the human gut are affected by human stress hormones, and if so, whether this interaction can affect the balance of the microbiota is currently 
not known.

For instance, whereas most medicinal drugs prescribed in clinical settings do not have an effect beyond the individual patient, the use of microbes in clinical settings may also have a direct physical impact on members of the patient¿s family or community. Thus, developing a deeper understanding of the human microbiome may lead to interventions that target public as well as individual health. In addition, given that human microbiota are much easier to manipulate than the human genome, the number of potential applications arising from human microbiome research may well dwarf that of research on the human genome. Given these unique circumstances, the advent of research into the human microbiome stands to benefit from a parallel effort to develop ethical guidelines to regulate such research and its applications. Social scientific research can help by informing such regulatory frameworks so that emerging technologies are applied in line with community values. This in turn will foster public trust in the research and facilitate basic and translational research on the human microbiome. Such a regulatory framework would be most effective if it were to draw on the input from experts, stakeholders, and the public. In this project, we propose to begin the process of collating and critically analysing the diversity of views and positions on human microbiome research and its applications. The project will focus on interviews with experts and stakeholders, such as scientists specializing in microbiology, genomics and related fields, disability advocates, clinicians, and public health officials. 173030,"Developing, implementing and evaluating self-audit as a knowledge translation strategy for practice-based learning and practice guideline implementation: A scoping review",Gagliardi  Anna R,"Gagliardi, Anna R","Sunnybrook Research Institute (Toronto, Ontario)",Ontario,Canada,200810,49223.0,Knowledge Synthesis Grant,Operating Grants,Health systems / services,Health Services and Policy Research,Continuing Professional Development; Guideline Implementation; Practice Guidelines; Scoping Review Of The Literature; Self-Directed Learning; Stakeholder Workshop,"Among health professionals, self-audit means reviewing one's own practice to identify problems and their cause, and understand how to improve the quality of health care services they provide. To maintain medical certification, physicians in Canada, the United Kingdom and United States are required to show annual proof of learning activities, including self-audit. Our research and that of others shows that family physicians and general surgeons spend little time on self-audit, mostly because they do not know how.  Practice guidelines are documents that summarize the most current research and provide physicians with recommendations for how to manage patients with different conditions. Simply producing guidelines does not mean they are used, as has been shown by numerous studies. International guideline experts suggest that physicians would more likely use guidelines if they contained, or were accompanied by tools that helped them compare their practice with guideline recommendations. Researchers analyzed many guidelines from different countries and found that most did not contain such information. Creation of self-audit tools could assist a greater number of physicians to more easily review their own practice. This would help them to conduct meaningful learning activities necessary to maintain medical certification, and adopt practice guideline recommendations. By doing so, they are equipped to deliver the best possible care to their patients. So that we can test self-audit tools in future research studies we will search the medical literature and Internet to learn more about the features of self-audit tools used successfully by others, and invite physician educators, medical licensing groups, practice guideline developers, family physicians and general surgeons to a one-day meeting where they will be asked to review the findings and suggest how we should develop a self-audit tool.",1 yr 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=173030&lang=en
