This research project proposes to examine how health professionals and managers, from different disciplines and organisations will adhere to recommendations forthcoming from the Quebec provincial stroke strategy, led by Heart and Stroke Quebec, and adopt national stroke best practices. More specifically, our study will examine factors that influence individual and organisational state-of-readiness to change and will examine processes used by health professionals and managers to meet individuals¿ expectations while respecting best practice recommendations. Complementing and extending the face-to-face activities of the Montreal Stroke Network, an electronic platform (e-collaborative website) will be developed, creating a networking environment that will provide capacity to capture knowledge sharing and evolution around members interactions on practice changes to be implemented. Stroke best practice recommendations will be presented on the platform in a pre-defined format and timeline in order to create ¿traffic jam¿, i.e, abundant threads of discussion. Researchers will act as moderators to ensure project identification aimed at implementing best practice recommendations. 173137,The Role of SPARC in Cancer Therapy Sensitization,Tai  Isabella T,"Tai, Isabella T",University of British Columbia,British Columbia,Canada,200809,300000.0,CIHR New Investigator,Salary Programs,Biomedical,Cancer Research,Cancer Biology; Cancer Genomics; Chemotherapy Resistance; Colorectal Cancer; Gene Expression,"The goal to improving mortality from cancer is to achieve complete response to therapy.  However, chemotherapy resistance has been a difficult problem to overcome. In order to better understand this phenomenon, our laboratory used a whole genome approach to obtain a snapshot of the changes that occur when cancer cells develop resistance to chemotherapy.  This allowed us to identify SPARC as a gene that may play a role in changing the sensitivity of cancer cells to chemotherapy.  We have been able to demonstrate that low SPARC levels in chemotherapy resistant human MIP101 colon cancer cells was associated with cancer cells that were resistant to therapy.  However, if SPARC was restored by either re-expressing this gene at higher levels, or by introducing the SPARC protein in tissue culture, colon cancer cells became more sensitive to chemotherapy.  In animal models, treatment with SPARC also allowed colon cancer cells to respond better to chemotherapy, and this was demonstrated by greater tumor regression in animals receiving SPARC with chemotherapy than in animals receiving chemotherapy alone. These exciting preliminary results serve as the basis of this research grant, as it proposes to study the mechanisms by which SPARC changes the sensitivity of colon cancer cells to chemotherapy.  The ultimate goal in understanding these mechanisms is the possibility of developing additional agents that would be useful in the treatment of colon cancer, especially in cases of previously failed cancer therapy.",5 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=173137&lang=en

The Québec BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) Vaccination Registry, currently kept at INRS-Institut Armand-Frappier, consists of approximately 4 million vaccination records from the 1920s to the mid 1990s. Alphabetical listings produced from the vaccination certificates are available in paper copy. Each vaccination record contains information on child's surname, child's given name, father's given name, birth date, sex, pre-vaccination test (type of test, date, and reaction in millimetres), current vaccination (date, mode of administration), date of prior vaccination, and medical institution. Computerization to convert these alphabetical paper listings into an electronic database is currently underway. Our study will assess the quality and accuracy of the computerized BCG registry. 173481,Identification of DNA-binding specificities for transcription factor pairs,Van Bakel  Harm,"Van Bakel, Harm",University of Toronto,Ontario,Canada,200810,75000.0,CIHR Fellowship,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,Genetics,Bioinformatics; Dimers; Dna Binding Motifs; Gene Regulation; Genetics; Genomics; Microarrays; Sequencing; Transcription; Transcription Factors,"DNA is often called the code of life and key elements in this code are genes, which provide the blueprints for making all proteins that form the building blocks needed to construct living cells. In recent years the full sequence of the human genome has been deciphered and the location of most genes is now known. An important question that remains, however, is how these genes are regulated in time and place. For example, genes that encode proteins needed to digest food must be turned on (expressed) in the gut, but not the brain. Cells therefore contain specialized proteins, known as transcription factors, which can selectively turn genes on or off by binding nearby in the genome. To find their targets, each of these factors recognizes a short unique sequence in the DNA. One complication is that these short motifs can occur at many places in the genome, often far outnumbering the genes that need to be expressed. One solution that cells use to increase the specificity of regulation is by letting transcription factors team up. A pair of transcription factors requires two motifs occurring together, with constraints on spacing and orientation, allowing for more precise gene targeting.
 Previous work in the Hughes lab has identified the individual DNA-binding motifs of a large number of transcription factors. However, evidence suggests that many of these factors actually work as pairs and therefore this project aims to identify their joint binding motifs. To do this we will let pairs of transcription factors combine together in a test tube and expose them to a mix of short DNA molecules that contain the motifs bound by each factor separately in all possible spacings and orientations. Deciphering which sequences transcription factor pairs bind will not only help us to answer basic questions of where and when genes are expressed, but also help to ultimately understand why this regulation sometimes goes awry in diseases such as cancer and during embryonic development.",1 yr 8 mths,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=173481&lang=en

It is unclear, however, whether these two syndromes represent distinct diagnostic categories or are on a continuum of severity. More precisely, is there a qualitatively distinct subgroup of individuals with Asperger syndrome characteristics, or what is called ""Asperger syndrome"" only represents a ""milder"" form of autism? This question is of prime importance, since if there are distinct subgroups of syndromes within the autistic spectrum, there is likely to be: i) distinct causes (e.g. distinct genetic variations); ii) distinct treatment options according to the strengths and limitations of the individual; and iii) distinct outcome in terms of everyday life functioning, for instance, in terms of professional orientations. The current project is aimed at providing arguments for or against the hypothesis of an Asperger syndrome entity within the autistic spectrum by using a data analysis approach specifically devised to investigate the existence of subcategories of individuals within a larger clinical entity (taxometric analyses). This project will be held at the Center of Excellence for Pervasive Developmental Disorder of University de Montréal (CETEDUM), with the Hôpital Rivière-des-Prairies internationally renowned specialists of autism (principal investigator: Dr Laurent Mottron). This project will thus benefit from careful and exhaustive evaluations of cognitive and behavioral strengths and limitations of more than four hundred patients with an autistic spectrum diagnosis.",2 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=173563&lang=en
173586,Sensory contributions to motor deficits after stroke: What is the role of the unaffected sensory cortex in motor recovery?,Meehan  Sean K,"Meehan, Sean K",University of British Columbia,British Columbia,Canada,200810,90000.0,CIHR Fellowship,Fellowship Programs,Clinical,"Neurosciences, Mental Health and Addiction",Diffusion Tensor Imaging; Learning; Magnetic Resonance Imaging; Motor; Rehabilitation; Sensorimotor Deficits; Sensory; Stroke; Training; Transcranial Magnetic Stimulaiton,"Movement related deficits after stroke are extremely common. It has been shown that deficits are related to an imbalance between the stroke affected and non-affected sides of the brain. Past research has focused on the possibility that hyperexcitability of the non-affected motor cortex furthers movement related disability after stroke. Constraining the unaffected limb has been associated with functional recovery of the affected limb, perhaps by reducing this imbalance. However, the mechanisms associated with these changes is unknown. Recently, studies mimicking constraint of the unaffected limb by numbing the non-affected hand, either by restricting blood flow or application of a local anesthetic, show transient increases in motor ability in the affected hand. While numbing reduces movement of the affected limb it also reduces the amount of sensory information arriving at the brain from the non-affected limb. It is likely that this reduction in sensory information changes the interaction between the two hemispheres via connections between the sensory and motor cortices that are essential for accurate movements, yet very little research has investigated the role of the non-affected sensory cortex. The purpose of the proposed research is to investigate how changes in non-affected sensory cortex influence sensorimotor processing in the affected cortex and whether these changes can be consolidated with motor learning. In contrast to past work, we will alter sensory processing in the non-affected cortex at the level of the brain using transcranial magnetic stimulation rather than in the periphery by numbing the hand. Importantly, understanding whether improved motor ability following sensory disruption in the non-affected hemisphere is mediated at the level of sensory cortex will allow rehabilitation interventions for individuals with stroke to be refined and improved. Our findings may offer a novel method with which to stimulate motor recovery after stroke.",2 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=173586&lang=en

Iron deficiency can lead to several severe pathologies such as anemia, while in excess it is toxic. Globally, anemia affects 1.62 billion people worldwide and half of which are preschool-age children. Matriptase-2 is a recently identified member of the type II transmembrane serine protease (TTSP) family. It is an enzyme predominantly located at the surface of liver cells and is capable of cutting other proteins to generate peptide fragments. Recent studies suggest that these peptide fragments are able to modulate iron balance and in an overactive state can lead to anemia. 
My working hypothesis is that Matriptase-2 is an essential regulator of iron homeostasis through its generation of novel signaling peptides. To confirm this hypothesis, Matriptase-2 targets in an anemia mouse model will be identified. Genetically modified mice that do not produce Matriptase-2, and their wild-type counterparts (control) will be employed. A comparison between the proteins contained in the outside environment of liver cells from each mouse strain will identify differences specific to the presence of Matriptase-2. To enrich for peptide fragments, a technique developed in our laboratory known as TAILS (Terminal Amine Isotopic Labeling of Substrate) will be applied. TAILS utilizes an in-house developed polymer to specifically select isotopically labeled N-termini. This enrichment will allow a better and specific identification of cleaved neo N-termini of natural protease substrates by mass spectrometry. Potential substrates will be identified and the direct action of the protease will be confirmed using standard biochemical techniques. The identification of the mechanisms by which Matriptase-2 influences the regulation of iron homeostasis will inform the rational development new drugs for iron deficiency and toxicity treatment.",2 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=173587&lang=en

HSCs divide following stress or injury, such as disease or blood loss, to help restore balance to the blood system. When necessary, HSCs divide; producing at least one identical copy of themselves to maintain the HSC population in addition to replenishing depleted blood cells in the case of blood loss, or increasing the number of blood cells in the case of infection. The signals in the body that cause HSCs to divide in this fashion are currently unknown.  Certain diseases, such as leukemia, require that the blood system be replaced by means of a bone marrow transplant.  The bone marrow, and the HSCs within it, comes from a donor therefore there is a chance of transplant failure.  Banking and using one's own HSC-rich cord blood would avoid donor transplant failure, unfortunately, there are not enough HSCs in an individual's cord blood to be used for transplantation and we currently do not have the ability to expand HSCs outside of the body.  The ability to culture and expand these rare HSCs would allow for transplantation of an individual's cells and would replace the current need for donor bone marrow, which is difficult and painful to obtain.  A protein called Nov was recently shown to expand HSCs in culture without causing them to loose their ability to reestablish the entire blood system.  It is unclear, however, how or what Nov is doing to cause this expansion of HSCs.  We will determine how Nov is affecting HSCs.  This will be done initially outside of the body in tissue culture and eventually using animal models. Although much is known about the allergic inflammatory events that occur during an asthma attack little is known about the structural changes termed airway remodeling which also occur and contribute toward the clinical symptoms of the disease. Airway remodeling can be defined as changes in the composition, content and organization of cellular and molecular constituents of the airway wall. These structural changes include epithelium detachment and expression of markers associated with tissue injury, sub epithelial fibrosis, increased smooth muscle mass, mucus gland hyperplasia and airway edema. The epithelium is a tissue composed of cells that lines the surfaces of the body including the lungs. As the epithelium within the airways is the first point of contact with the external environment and inhaled aeroallergens it is a logical target to determine the mechanisms of airway remodeling in allergic asthma. The apical junction complex (AJC) forms the structural cell-cell adhesion junctions which regulate permeability across the epithelium and acts as a rate limiting barrier to penetration of inhaled environmental stimuli. However, recent studies have now demonstrated that AJCs are important for the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation which are both important for normal epithelial repair following injury. We will determine if AJCs play an important role in epithelial repair and if these mechanisms are altered in asthma. This application is important as airway remodeling in established asthma is poorly responsive to current therapies such as inhaled corticosteroids and reliever medications. We predict that specific signaling enzymes in the cell are responsible for inducing the increase in pHi observed in cancer cell. The first aim of my research is to identify signaling molecules that induce the increased pHi and examine their role in the induction and progression of cancer. Additionally, an increase in pHi of ~0.4 promotes cancer cell progression and the spread of cancer cells in metastasis. However, how an alkaline pHi generates a ""go"" signal for cancer progression is unknown. A second prediction is that specific proteins in cells that promote cancer are turned on at alkaline pH but not the neutral pH of normal cells. If we can discover which proteins are ""pH sensors"" and are activated at higher pH we can develop therapeutics that block their pH-dependent function as an approach to halt the progression and spread of cancer. The second aim of my research is to identify proteins that are activated by increased pHi and to test their function in promoting cancer. To achieve this we developed cell models we can use to experimentally change pHi and strategies to purify and identify proteins that are turned on at the alkaline pHi of cancer cells but not at the neutral pHi of normal cells. Indeed, the loss of synaptic structures is the most fundamental change in neurodegenerative diseases, as it encompasses the basis of the collapse of brain function and is the only strong correlate of cognitive decline. Although synaptic loss has been repeatedly reported in different disease entities including Alzheimer's disease (AD), the mechanism underlying their disappearance is not well understood. Synaptic loss is often viewed as a change secondary to the toxic effects of the abnormal proteins such as beta-amyloid, or as a consequence of overall neuronal death.  However, the load and location of abnormal proteins do not correlate very well with the clinical severity of the dementia and recent data clearly indicates that clearing of the toxic amyloid does not lead to cognitive improvement but rather no change in the course of the disease.
In this study, we aim at combining emerging technologies from imaging, molecular and proteomics to study the underlying mechanisms leading to the loss of synapses in an animal model of AD. In particular, surgical site infections lead to longer hospital stays, more patient suffering, increased mortality, and greater economic costs for hospitals and health care systems.  These adverse events arise from a complex interaction of pathogen, patient and procedural factors.  Strategies to prevent surgical site infections, therefore, must be broad based targeting preoperative, intraoperative and postoperative risk factors.
     Effective surgical site infection surveillance systems are vital to detect these novel risk factors for infection, provide benchmark infection rates, and identify substandard processes.  The gold standard has been clinical surveillance networks, but the intensive labour and financial costs of these systems limit the extent of participating hospitals, the capacity for outpatient follow up, and the ability to account for different levels of risk.  Datasets extracted from administrative logs offer another potential source of surveillance, with advantages of population-based data, cost-efficiency, outpatient follow-up, and robust risk adjustment.
     This research program will aim to harness administrative and clinical datasets for the surveillance, evaluation, prevention and science of infections after surgery. patients having surgery for liver cancer will be used to grow human liver tumors in mice. Tumor cells with 
different protein signatures will be tested for their abilities to self-renew as well as generate complete human 
liver cancers in the mice, which are the hallmarks of cancer stem cells. Once the cancer stem cells can be 
identified, they will be analyzed for features that are responsible for distinct patterns of tumor growth that are 
seen in different patients. In addition, the liver cancer stem cells will be compared with mature cells and stem 
cells from normal liver to better understand how the cancer stem cells develop and function. Finally, the ability to
grow human liver tumors in mice will be used to study the effects of different drugs on the ability of liver cancer

173692,Development of Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Urea Cycle Defects,Campeau  Philippe M,"Campeau, Philippe M",McGill University,Texas,United States of America,200809,187500.0,CIHR Clinician Scientist - Phase 1,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,Genetics,Enzyme Replacement Therapy; Genetic Disorders; Inborn Errors Of Metabolism; Protein Transduction; Urea Cycle Defects,"Urea cycle defects (UCDs) are frequent genetic disorders, affecting up to 1/8200 children, and are notably difficult to treat, causing severe neurologic disease and early death. Novel therapies are urgently needed. Gene therapy is promising, but issues limiting its use include the difficulty in obtaining a sustained correction, and the immune reactions limiting re-administration of the vectors. An interesting therapeutic avenue is enzyme replacement therapy (ERT), which has permitted great advances in the treatment of lysosomal storage diseases (other genetic diseases). To apply such a therapy to UCDs, the intravenously injected enzyme should reach the interior of liver cells. This can be done by modifying the enzyme (adding a portion called a protein transduction domain, which will permit efficient cell entry) and injecting this enzyme intravenously. 173715,Role of chromatin modifications in meiotic double strand break (DSB) formation and repair,Sapountzi  Vasileia,"Sapountzi, Vasileia",Universit&eacute; Laval,Qu&eacute;bec,Canada,200810,97500.0,CIHR Fellowship,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,Cancer Research,Ageing; Chromatin; Chromatin Immunoprecipitation; Dna Damage; Histone Acetylation; Meiosis; Protein Complex Purification/Analysis,"DNA is a biomolecule that carries the hereditary information which is needed for the construction and maintenance of the living organism. Cells have elaborate ways of packaging DNA, for reasons of compaction and organisation. DNA is tightly bound to a scaffold comprising molecules called histones; this forms a structure called 'chromatin'.
Apart from its compaction role, chromatin also protects DNA from breaking: various agents, originating from inside the cell (such as toxic by-products of metabolism) or the cell's environment (such as carcinogenic pollutants and radiation) can generate breaks along the DNA molecule.
The majority of these breaks are extremely dangerous, as they result in loss of genetic information and/or genetic mistakes. Cells with untreated DNA breaks cannot function properly and this is often the underlying reason of diseases such as cancer.
However, not all breaks are lethal; pre-programmed DNA breaks occur naturally during meiosis, the biological process important for reproduction. The DNA breaks in meiosis are actually very important for the inheritance of genetic information to future generations.
Whether accidental or pre-programmed, DNA breaks need to be treated promptly in order to ensure that the cell survives the damage and continues to function properly. The way that the cells detect and repair DNA breaks is not yet clear, but is the topic of an expanding field of molecular biology. Recent evidence suggests that chromatin plays an active role in this process.
In this project, we are planning to study in more detail how chromatin affects the formation and repair of DNA breaks during meiosis. If one understands how pre-programmed DNA breaks are generated and repaired, one will be able to understand how carcinogen-generated DNA breaks occur and can be prevented. One will also be able to utilise this information in order to design therapies of
diseases resulting from these agents, such as cancer.",2 yrs 2 mths,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=173715&lang=en

During pregnancy, mother and fetus constantly exchange materials (nutrients, gases and waste products) with each other via the placenta.  Recently, exchanges of cells and/or DNA have also been detected.  Surprisingly, many years after their physical union is severed, maternal microchimerism can be found in her adult offspring and fetal microchimerism in the mother.  These recent findings challenge the traditional view of self and point to the potential for both good and bad consequences for human health.  In humans, maternal and fetal microchimerism has been identified in blood, heart, kidney, pancreas and spleen.  No prior study has tested the brain.  That human brain is likely to include microchimerism is supported by recent experimental studies that found fetal and maternal microchimerism in mouse brain.  Therefore, the overall goal of this project is for the first time to identify, quantify and characterize microchimerism in the human brain, particularly fetal microchimerism in women.  Once the prevalence, quantity and phenotype of microchimerism have been established, we may extend our studies to selective brain diseases.  Effects of microchimerism in the brain could either be beneficial (tissue repair, tumor immune surveillance or normal development) or adverse (targets of immune attack, accessory to degenerative changes or neoplasia).  As there is currently no information regarding naturally acquired microchimerism in the human brain, this project will be the first to explore this new frontier and provide a useful basis of knowledge for future studies of normal development of the brain (including aging) and specific brain diseases.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=174017&lang=en

White matter injury, abnormal brain development and systemic illness are interrelated abnormalities that commonly follow preterm birth and may lead to adverse neurodevelopment. Focal non-cystic white matter injury is the characteristic pattern of brain injury in premature newborns. Though focal non-cystic white matter injury is associated with diffuse abnormalities of motor and cognitive function, how this happens is unknown. Systemic illness, such as infection, and therapy, such as postnatal corticosteroids, may also be associated with diffuse abnormalities of motor and cognitive function. The mechanisms by which these conditions cause abnormal outcome are largely unknown. Preliminary data suggest that white matter injury and specific systemic conditions, such as infection, diffusely impair brain development. The overall hypothesis of this prospective cohort study is that delayed brain development, due to systemic illness and white matter injury, results in abnormal motor and cognitive outcome. We will quantify brain development and injury in premature newborns using advanced magnetic resonance (MR) techniques shortly after birth and again at term-equivalent age: deformation tensor morphometry for anatomic brain structure, diffusion tensor imaging for brain connectivity and MR spectroscopic imaging for brain metabolism. 174082,The stringent response and 4-hydroxy-2-alkylquinolines: a mechanism of antibiotic tolerance in Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms?,Nguyen  Dao,"Nguyen, Dao",McGill University,Qu&eacute;bec,Canada,200809,300000.0,CIHR Clinician Scientist - Phase 2,Salary Programs,Biomedical,Infection and Immunity,Antibiotic Resistance; Biofilms; Cystic Fibrosis; Molecular Microbiology; Pseudomonas Aeruginosa; Respiratory Infection,"Chronic bacterial infections are difficult to treat and often cannot be cleared by antibiotics. A devastating example of such infection is the Pseudomonas aeruginosa airway infection in patients with the genetic disease cystic fibrosis. Most patients acquire the infection early in life and remain chronically infected for the rest of their lives despite aggressive antibiotic therapies. These chronic infections cause severe respiratory symptoms, decline in lung function and ultimately death from respiratory failure. 

One important reason why antibiotics fail to eradicate the chronic infections is because they are caused by biofilms. Biofilms are a form of growth where bacteria live in structured clusters, embedded in a polymer matrix. Bacteria growing in biofilms are very resistant to antibiotics and the host¿s immune system and the mechanisns of this resistance are still largely unknown. 

Our preliminary studies showed that a stress response called the stringent response is important to the bacteria¿s ability to grow and stay alive in biofilms, and to be resistant to antibiotics. The stringent response is a mechanism that allows bacteria to adapt to starvation and many stressful conditions. We also found that the stringent response regulate a family of molecules called 4-hydroxy-2-alkylquinolines and these may be involved in the antibiotic resistance of biofilms. 

We are interested in understanding how the stringent response are involved in antibiotic resistance. Our studies are focused on understanding how the stringent response regulates these quinoline molecules, on defining the exact role of these molecules in biofilm antibiotic resistance, and examining whether these findings could be useful for development of future therapies against biofilm infections. With the lack of new antibiotics in development and the severe health burden of biofilm infections, new treatment strategies that target biofilms are much needed.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=174082&lang=en
174083,Role and mechanisms of endothelial transcytosis during inflammation,Lee  Warren L,"Lee, Warren L",University of Toronto,Ontario,Canada,200809,300000.0,CIHR Clinician Scientist - Phase 2,Salary Programs,Biomedical,Circulatory and Respiratory Health,Cell Biology; Electron Microscopy; Endothelium; Inflammation; Live Cell Imaging; Sepsis,"Inflammation is the hallmark of many diseases, including sepsis (blood-poisoning).  Sepsis can develop when the body is infected with bacteria.  Even after patients receive antibiotics, sepsis may persist and, in its most severe form, can lower the patient's blood pressure so much that the patient's organs do not receive enough blood or oxygen.  This complication, known as septic shock, leads to failure of multiple organs and has a very high mortality rate.  
    It is known that patients with septic shock become excessively swollen, with fluid accumulation (edema) both in the extremities and internal organs.   Blood vessels of patients with sepsis are leaky, allowing fluid to escape and accumulate in the surrounding tissues.  This vascular leak prevents organs from receiving enough oxygen and may contribute to organ failure.  All the blood vessels in the body are lined by a layer of specialized cells known as endothelium.  One of the main functions of endothelium is to prevent leakage of fluid by maintaining an intact barrier.  The goal of my research is to understand how inflammatory states like sepsis degrade the barrier function of blood vessels, leading to edema.  Ultimately, this research may help to identify new drug targets for diseases like sepsis.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=174083&lang=en

174214,Defining the Molecular Events Linking Growth Factor-Induced Signaling with the G1 Cell Cycle Program,Pennock  Steven D,"Pennock, Steven D","Harvard Medical School (Boston, Massachusetts)",Massachusetts,United States of America,200810,150000.0,CIHR Fellowship,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,Cancer Research,Cancer; Cell Cycle; Cell Proliferation; Growth Factors; Multiplexing; Protein Phosphorylation; Proteomics; Signal Transduction; Tumorigenesis; Tyrosine Kinases,"Cell division is a fundamental process of life, and a process ruinously exploited by cancer.   Although it is well established that cells proliferate in response to growth factors, there remains a profound gap in understanding how the initial step of growth factor stimulation leads to a cellular commitment to divide.  Work from our lab has revealed that growth factors are required at two distinct stages in order to drive cell proliferation.  The first stage is a result of initial exposure to growth factor where resting cells are aroused and primed for further stimulation several hours later.  At this later time, further exposure to growth factor initiates the second stage, allowing primed cells to directly engage the cellular machinery required to cause proliferation. Although scientists have an excellent appreciation of the events initiated within minutes of the first stage and of the events following the second stage, the molecular events that entail ""priming"" and thus link these two stages are completely unknown.  The importance in understanding these intermediate events is vital not only at a fundamental level, but to understanding exactly how hyperproliferative diseases (e.g. cancer) function at the cellular level.  This proposal has two aims.  The first aim is to define the molecular events linking the two growth factor-dependent stages required for cell proliferation.  It is our hypothesis that growth factors prime cells by inducing the expression of specific proteins.  The second aim will be to test how priming and the associated priming proteins contribute to tumour development in animals.  We hypothesize that priming is an essential component of tumour development and that suppressing the function of priming proteins will suppress the onset of cancer. Apoptosis of the cell occurs through the action of a family of proteins called caspases.  Another family of genes, the IAPs (inhibitor of apoptosis proteins) has been shown to bind with and block the action of caspases.  Our research examines the efficacy of using XIAP (X-linked IAP) to prevent apoptosis in several forms of retinal degeneration.  XIAP has been shown to interact with and inhibit the action of several caspases.  It has previously been shown that XIAP provides a significant degree of protection in animal models of neurodegenerative disease such as stroke, Parkinson's and Huntington's disease.  We have shown that XIAP can prevent cell death in animal models of retinal ischemia, retinal detachment and in genetic forms of retinitis pigmentosa (RP). We believe that these studies provide significant proof-of-principle for XIAP efficacy in the treatment of human retinal disease. Currently used immunoassays employ other detection mechanisms such as radioactivity, enzyme activity, fluorescence or luminescence. Preliminary results indicate that the new method is at least  as sensitive and reproducible as the conventional approaches, but is much simpler, faster and cheaper. Because of this, it is expected that the method could be used in hospitals as a Point of Care procedure for diagnosis. This means that the patient's sample could be immediately analyzed in the hospital ward rather than sending it to a central lab. Another advantage is the possibility of being able to simultaneously measure several different substances in the same sample. The method has been successfully applied to the measurement of a protein. Results obtained thus far have been protected by a patent application, now at the international stage.

 

The team is now planning to adapt the method to the measurement of small molecules, which could then be used for therapeutic drug monitoring, detection of drugs of abuse, and analysis of certain hormones. They will also determine if the method can be used on whole blood. The third aspect of the project is to design and assemble a simple ultrasound device dedicated to this new application.

 

Immunoassay is widely used for diagnostic purposes in cancer, endocrinology, infectious diseases and other areas. The total annual world market for reagents and devices is several billion dollars. The new technology being developed at McGill will improve health care by providing a new in vitro diagnostic technology that is faster and  more economical than existing approaches",1 yr 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=174439&lang=en

We studied this process in the context of brain tumors (gliomas) and found that a cancer-causing molecule called EGFRvIII is a part of microvesicles found in blood of tumor-bearing mice and patients. Patients whose tumors have EGFRvIII may have a much worse disease than those who do not.  
We postulate that by testing whether tumor derived bubbles/microvesicles present in the patient's blood contain EGFRvIII or related protein EGFR, it may be possible to know how bad the tumor is, and whether treatment given to patients really works.  
We will develop an assay that could detect EGFR and EGFRVIII trapped in blood borne microvesicles with a greater accuracy and test this assay in various tumors expressing EGFRvIII or EGFR. together. In addition, we have developed a treatment whereby 
the patent is presented with stimuli tailored to their particular

is gradually reduced over time until both eyes can work together 
under normal viewing conditions.  This is a breakthrough, as

Although there are various reasons for low rates of participation in testing and treatment programmes, an understudied factor is the effect of conspiracy beliefs.  A recent study (Bogart et al 2008) showed that people who endorsed a genocidal conspiracy belief (e.g.""HIV was created by Whites to kill Blacks"") were less likely to have an HIV test.  Ethnographic research by Steinberg (2007) suggests that conspiracy belief is also an important impediment to seeking treatment with antiretroviral medication.  The political and historical origins of such beliefs are persuasive: generations of an Apartheid government that actively researched biological and chemical weapons that could be used against ANC insurgents, as well as recent 'AIDS denialism' by the former President Mbeki and his colleagues has lent credibility to the notion that HIV/AIDS is man-made, and that health programmes may not be benevolent. 175128,The role of pannexin1 in regulation of transmission of visual stimuli in the adult mammalian retina,Sorbara  Catherine D,"Sorbara, Catherine D","Harvard Medical School (Boston, Massachusetts)",Massachusetts,United States of America,200810,54000.0,CIHR Doctoral Research Award,Studentship Programs,Biomedical,"Neurosciences, Mental Health and Addiction",Gap Junctions; Hemichannels; Lentivirus; Pannexin; Retina; Transgenic Animal Model; Visual Signaling,"Retinal disease is the leading cause of blindness in adults in North America and is becoming more prevalent in our aging population. Current treatments have limited efficacy while therapeutic improvements involve understanding the complex molecular events of visual signaling. In the retina, gap junctions are established by many cell types and participate in retinal circuitry in a variety of ways. Canonical gap junctions are formed by the oligomerization of 6 connexin protein subunits called a connexon or hemichannel. Two connexons from adjacent cells align to form a gap junction, serving as a conduit for small molecules to pass and providing an electrical syncytium. This network is hypothesized to contribute to degeneration in retinal diseases by mediating the passage of noxious substances from dying rod cells to otherwise healthy cone cells. Recently it was shown that pannexin family of proteins was also expressed in retinal ganglion cells, amacrine and horizontal cells. Pannexin is a newly discovered putative gap junction protein. Pannexin1 (Panx1) hemichannels have gained a great amount of attention due to their capacity to open at physiological concentrations of calcium, unlike connexons. Hemichannels are believed to play an important role in the retina as a negative feedback pathway from horizontal cells to cones. Futhermore, Panx1 has the ability to pass signaling molecules such as ATP. Panx1 has been linked to the release of ATP in the retina following elevated hydrostatic pressure providing a mechanism for neuronal damage and death of ganglion cells in acute glaucoma. Together, these findings suggest a potentially important and indispensable role of pannexins in electrical or metabolic coupling between cells in the retina. 175247,INDEL therapeutics for the treatment of infectious disease.,Reiner  Neil E,"Reiner, Neil E",University of British Columbia,British Columbia,Canada,200810,250000.0,Proof of Principle Program - Phase II,Operating Grants,Biomedical,Infection and Immunity,Drug Development; Infectious Disease; Medicinal Chemistry; Nosocomial Infections; Rational Drug Design,"The INDEL platform was the recipient of a Proof of Principle I grant in 2004, which successfully validated the science and allowed the creation of a University of British Columbia start-up company, INDEL Therapeutics Inc.  The platform technology enables the discovery of new therapeutics for the treatment of infectious diseases. 
INDEL views the continued exchange between scientific advancement and microbial resistance in a revolutionary way. Bioinformatics and molecular modeling have grown in sophistication and predictive power, allowing INDEL to identify and target discreet differences in essential pathogen proteins that have a common counterpart in human cells. These differences between almost identical pathogen and human proteins are called indel-differentiated regions. The similarity observed between these pathogenic proteins and their human counterparts illustrates a shared essential function within the cell, conserved through strong evolutionary pressure.  Pathogenic indel-differentiated targets do not readily permit mutation since they are critical cellular hubs and are absolutely essential for pathogen survival. As a result, when INDEL develops a novel therapeutic, its indel-differentiated target will be less likely to mutate and allow the organism to become resistant, since mutations will mean loss of function and pathogen death.
INDEL has demonstrated its ability to discover small molecule compounds against its pathogenic indel-differentiated targets. Using unique expertise in computer (in silico) rational drug design, we have identified therapeutics that can bind to specific indel-differentiated targets and inhibit their function, while showing no interaction, and thus toxicology concerns with the human counterpart protein. Proceeds from the Proof of Principle II grant will be used to creates small molecule leads against several Indel Platform targets for the treatment of infectious disease.",1 yr 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=175247&lang=en

175659,Enteric glial P2X7 receptors in inflammatory bowel disease,Gulbransen  Brian D,"Gulbransen, Brian D",University of Calgary,Alberta,Canada,200810,60000.0,CAG/CIHR Fellowship for Research in Gastroenterology/Nutrition,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,"Nutrition, Metabolism and Diabetes",Colitis; Enteric; Glia; Guinea Pig; Inflammation; Mouse; Myenteric; Neurodegeneration; P2x7; Purinergic,"Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is increasingly prevalent and approximately 10,000 new cases are diagnosed in Canada every year. While the underlying mechanisms causing IBD are unknown, recent advances demonstrate that the enteric nervous system (ENS) plays a key role. In the central nervous system (CNS), glial cells are critical mediators of inflammation. During pathological conditions, astrocytes and microglia release excitatory amino acids, ATP, and proinflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-1&#946; through ionotropic purinergic P2X7 receptors (P2X7Rs), causing proinflammatory responses, neurodegeneration, and the development of chronic and neuropathic pain. Like CNS neurons, enteric neurons are surrounded and far outnumbered by a distinct type of peripheral glial cell called enteric glia. Molecular and morphological similarities between enteric glia and CNS astrocytes suggest they fulfill similar roles but the functional role of enteric glia remains largely unknown, although enteric glia have been implicated in the development of intestinal inflammation. In industrialized countries, enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) causes a more severe diarrhea and can progress to a fatal kidney disease. 

The route of bacterial infections often occurs by the ingestion or inhalation of the bacteria. Once inside the host, the bacteria replicate and seek to exit the host to spread to a new susceptible host. This dissemination of bacteria is called transmission and can occur through various means such as insect bites, fecal shedding or, aerosols created by sneezing or coughing. Both EPEC and EHEC are transmitted through the fecal-oral route, with an infectious dose of EHEC being less than 100 cells. Sources of contamination can range from direct contact with symptomatic or asymptomatic carriers, food, drinking water or petting zoos and farms. To put this into perspective, the 2000 EHEC outbreak in Walkerton, Ontario was caused by contaminated drinking water and resulted in 2300 cases and 7 deaths. This exemplifies the serious public health concern posed by these pathogens.

Little is known about strategies that pathogens use to transmit from host to host. My research aims to identify these strategies and determine how they contribute to the spread of disease. This project will lay the groundwork for the largely understudied area of bacterial transmission. The identification of strategies involved in transmission will provide insights and increase our general understanding of transmission. It involves specific determinants of anterior (brain) and posterior (spinal cord) fates. In the posterior embryo, the first step of neurulation involves the generation of a sheet of cells called the neural plate. Through different processes, the neural plate is then shaped in a closed neural tube, the spinal cord precursor. From the dorsal neural tube, a specific subpopulation of cells, called the neural crest cells, emigrate to generate the peripheral nervous system. These cells have stem cell properties allowing them to also contribute other specialized cell types such as pigment cells (melanocytes), some hormone-producing cells and some muscle cells of the cardio-vascular system. Problems affecting neural tube closure as well as neural crest cells development are the cause of many birth defects or genetic syndromes, such as spina bifida and aganglionic megacolon. Misregulations of neural crest cells development are also responsible of many cancers from childhood to adulthood such as neuroblastoma, neurofibroma and malignant melanoma. A better understanding of neural tube formation and neural crest cells function at the molecular level is therefore required to allow identification of predisposed individuals as well as facilitating diagnosis and treatment of the related illnesses. Members of the Cdx protein family (Cdx1, Cdx2 and Cdx4) are specific determinants of posterior fates and they are active in the early developing spinal cord, starting well before the formation of a neural tube. They are also active in pre-migratory and early migratory neural crest cells. However, the Cdx function in these cells is still not clear because of a lack of a good experimental model. 175910,CIHR Emerging team grant: Co-morbidities of Traumatic Brain Injury in Children and Youth,Hutchison  James S,"Hutchison, James S",Hospital for Sick Children (Toronto),Ontario,Canada,200810,4920.0,Emerging Team Grant: Co-morbidity of brain disorders &amp; other health problems-LOI,Operating Grants,Clinical,"Neurosciences, Mental Health and Addiction",Biomarkers; Co-Morbidities; Neuroimaging; Quality Of Life; Traumatic Brain Injury,"Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is the leading cause of acquired disability in children. Co-morbid cognitive and mental health conditions may predispose to the injury, and may be worsened following the injury, but have not been well characterized. A better understanding may provide insight into pathophysiology and new approaches for prevention and treatment. Furthermore, the incidence of co-morbid mental health conditions as children with TBI transition to adulthood is unknown. Objective: To determine the impact of mental health co-morbidites on quality of life (QOL) of children with TBI. Primary outcome: Conners' Adult ADHD Rating Scales (study 1) and the Conners III Parent and Teacher Rating Scales in children (study 2). Study 1: A cross sectional case-control design will be used to examine the incidence of cognitive and mental health co-morbidities in young adults aged 20-25 who experienced a severe TBI between the age 1 month to 17 years from the Hospital for Sick Children. Age, sex and socioeconomic group-matched controls with no TBI (N=50) will also be recruited. All subjects will be interviewed to assess mental health co-morbidities, functional and neuropsychological outcomes and QOL. Regression analysis will be used to determine which co-morbidities are associated with poor QOL. Study 2: Prospective longitudinal case-control study -2 year follow-up. Children with mild to severe TBI (N=100), 5-17 years, admitted to the PICUs of 8 children's hospitals in Canada will be included. Controls will be critically ill children with no brain injury. Co-morbidities will be assesed at baseline (pre-injury) and at follow-up, combined with assessment of functional, neuropsychological and QOL outcomes at 12 and 24 months. Hierarchical Linear Models will be used to determine the association between clinical correlates and long term outcomes. Significance: These novel results will change the way we assess and treat cognitive and mental health co-morbidities in children with TBI.",1 yr 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=175910&lang=en
175912,The psychiatric and somatic comorbidities of epilepsy - the development of prospective multicenter cohorts using observational and administrative data.,Jette  Nathalie,"Jette, Nathalie; Burneo, Jorge G; Patten, Scott B; Pohlmann-Eden, Bernhard; Tellez-Zenteno, Jose F",University of Calgary,Alberta,Canada,200810,5000.0,Emerging Team Grant: Co-morbidity of brain disorders &amp; other health problems-LOI,Operating Grants,,,Administrative Data; Cohort; Epilepsy; Health Related Behaviors And Health Outcome; Health Services; Psychiatric Comorbidities; Surveillance,"Epilepsy is the second most common neurological condition worldwide, second only to headache. One in every 10 person has at least one seizure in their life. Many of these people go on to develop epilepsy, characterized by repeated, unpredictable seizures. Epilepsy affects people of all ages, gender, and socio-economic status. Epilepsy imposes a significant burden on patients, their families, and society and this burden is even greater if those with epilepsy who have other conditions (known as comorbidities).  

Studies show that those with epilepsy are more likely to have other conditions, including psychiatric (e.g. major depression) or medical conditions (e.g. migraine, stroke, diabetes). It is not known whether epilepsy is causing these other comorbidities, or vice versa. One way to answer this question is to develop epilepsy cohorts: epidemiological studies that allow us to record information from a group of new patients with epilepsy over time.  

Our objectives will be to: (1) develop epilepsy cohorts to record comorbidities before and after epilepsy diagnosis; (2) develop a tool which will help health providers determine which person with epilepsy should be referred for a mental health evaluation; (3) test our tool in a large group of those with epilepsy to see if applying it improves their overall health and quality of life.

Developing cohorts is crucial in order to improve the capacity to conduct epilepsy surveillance which is currently non existent in Canada. The availability of epilepsy cohorts to study comorbidities and other outcomes will improve planning, coordination and evaluation of overall health care needs, burden of epilepsy and its comorbidities. It will help us ensure proper resources are in place for those with epilepsy. Finally, developing a rating tool to identify those with epilepsy who should be referred for a mental health evaluation should improve their overall health.",1 yr 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=175912&lang=en

To achieve this level of compaction, small proteins known as histones help the formation and organisation of the genome into chromatin and chromosomes. This extensive compaction of the genetic material put an incredible constraint on the availability of the genetic information. In order to regulate the genetic information accessibility, the histones are temporally and spacially modified by small molecules, which facilitate the timely compaction or relaxation of discreet regions of DNA. One such histone modification, lysine methylation (Kme), is laid down by lysine methyltranferase (KMT) enzymes. Several KMTs have clear links to cancer, suggesting a central role for this modification in maintaining cellular homeostasis and in neoplastic disease. Dynamic Kme of histone proteins regulates diverse cellular functions. In contrast, the biological functions of Kme on non-histone proteins, while rapidly evolving, is largely unexplored. Accumulating evidence suggests that small protein domains are involved in specific recognition and readout of the methyl marks. The field of Kme of non-histone proteins, still in its infancy, lacks the ""tools"" to easily and efficiently identify novel KMT substrates and sensors of this modification. I have therefore been involved in the development of a proteomic approach, using click chemistry, to identify by an unbiased approach additional KMT substrates. In parallel, I have developped an impartial screening method to identify novel sensors of Kme events. We also know that tissue repair is delayed as we get older. One possibility is that as we age, we accumulate tired cells that no longer divide: senescent cells. Our hypothesis is that accumulation of senescent cells in the microenvironment of stem cells prevents adequate regeneration of tissues. This hypothesis is supported by results we obtained showing that senescent cells are deficient in the activation of certain responses required for tissue repair following an injury. Also, in comparison to normal cells, senescent cells secrete molecules that may influence stem cell response. In conclusion, our objective is to identify how the accumulation of senescent cells possibly impairs tissue regeneration. This disease, although phenotypically manifested as cognitive deficits, exhibits pathologic traits that are suggestive of a systemic disorder. One school of thought puts A at center-stage of immune reactions leading to the development of a chronic inflammatory process. According to this hypothesis, during the early phases of AD, immunity seeks to eliminate the overproduced A in the periphery by mounting a beneficial (acute) inflammatory response, resulting in T cell activation and production of specific antibodies. Thus, the cellular immune response may play a crucial role in protection via antigenic activation. Consistent with such a role in defence, A-reactive cells are also found in healthy persons. These are often associated with infection by the common persistent Herpes virus HHV5 (cytomegalovirus, CMV). However, CMV infection has been linked to cognitive impairment in the elderly in longitudinal studies. CMV might thus be one of the prime driving forces behind many of the alterations associated with immunosenescence and the manner in which CMV and the host immune system interact might also contribute in determining the ""age"" of adaptive immunity and hence age-associated diseases such as AD. 176454,Pathogenesis of tendinopathy: Clinical and laboratory studies,Miran-Khan  Karim,"Miran-Khan, Karim; Duronio, Vincent",University of British Columbia,British Columbia,Canada,200809,100000.0,"Operating Grant - PA: Musculoskeletal Health, Arthritis, Skin and Oral Health",Operating Grants,Clinical,Musculoskeletal Health and Arthritis,Repetitive Use Injuries; Tendinopathy; Tendon,"Repetitive-use tendon injury (traditionally called 'tendinitis' is a major clinical burden in many Canadian industries. There is only limited understanding of how this condition develops; the term for development of a medical condition is called 'pathogenesis'. If we understand the factors that initiate tendon damage in repetive-use jobs like at checkout counters or in the lumber or fishing industries, we will be in a much better position to develop effective treatments. 

When studying painful, damaged tendon from patients undergoing surgery for long-term tendon pain, we (and others) have found that the blood vessels in the damaged area are very abnormal. There are an excessively large number of small vessels - 'microvessels'. We have shown that these vessels are increasing in number (proliferating) and producing a factor that stimulate futher vessel development. This is called vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). A commonly-used clinical diagnostic test - ultrasound scanning - has shown that increased tendon vascularity is associated with tendon pain. (But the relationship is not perfect.)

Thus, there is a good reason to investigate whether tendon vessels proliferate during periods of repetitive-use as a result of local VEGF production. 176456,Resistance to feeding-induced anabolism with immobilization in skeletal muscle proteins in humans,Phillips  Stuart M,"Phillips, Stuart M",McMaster University,Ontario,Canada,200809,66624.0,"Operating Grant - PA: Musculoskeletal Health, Arthritis, Skin and Oral Health",Operating Grants,Biomedical,Musculoskeletal Health and Arthritis,Protein Breakdown; Protein Synthesis; Signalling; Skeletal Muscle; Stable Isotope; Tensegrity,"Many people have broken their leg or arm. After wearing a cast for some 4-8 weeks one would have observed firsthand how our leg or arm are much smaller and 'flabby' after the cast was removed. This is because our muscle loses its tone and is much smaller in size. This process, known as muscle atrophy, means we lose strength and muscle size. In other situations, such as during a prolonged period of bed rest, in which our limbs are not bearing weight and so are 'unloaded' the loss of strength and muscle size can become a much greater problem. The rehabilitation of persons who have been in prolonged bed rest is substantial and very costly. It would be advantageous to lessen and reduce the loss of skeletal muscle in persons who are immobilized due to casting or during periods of bed rest. Regrettably, we are largely ignorant as to the exact reason(s) why our muscles become smaller and lose their strength. Our theory is that during the unloading of our limbs during casting or when we lay in bed for a long time that a signal, or more correctly a lack of a signal, in our muscles triggers a reduction in the rate at which new proteins are made. In general, new proteins are continuously made to replace old damaged proteins. Maintenance of all protein-containing structures in our muscle relies on this constant ongoing replacing of old damaged proteins with new ones. Thus, if we make new proteins at a much slower rate than the olds ones are removed and not replaced; the result is a smaller, weaker protein structure or an atrophied muscle. The nature of the signal during that triggers a reduced rate of manufacture of new proteins during unloading has been elusive. Myelin is the protective coating on nerves that enables them to conduct signals from the brain to other parts of the body. When myelin is destroyed, nerve conduction is disrupted, resulting in such symptoms as muscle weakness, blindness, loss of sensation, and cognitive dysfunction. 
      For reasons that are unclear, MS affects women three times more often than men. The goal of our research program is to determine the underlying reasons for sex-based differences in the prevalence of MS. To this end, we conduct studies using the animal model of MS, experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). Previous work by our group and others has revealed that sex differences in the development of EAE may relate in part to the ability of male sex hormones (androgens) to dampen the activity of myelin-reactive T cells. Additionally, we have made progress towards identifying the genes that mediate the effects of androgens on the immune response. Our studies have shown that male sex hormones induce the expression of Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor alpha (PPARalpha) in T cells and that this gene has suppressive effects on the activity of these cells.
      The major objective of our research is to study in more depth the mechanism of how male sex hormones limit the activity of myelin-reactive T cells in EAE and to test the hypothesis that these hormones suppress the activity of T cells by increasing the expression of PPARalpha. Finally, optimal performance is generally required of subjects, which is not a parameter of importance for daily motor activities of seniors, given that energy conservation is typically their goal. Accordingly, the motor acts performed under these tests do not provide an accurate representation of everyday life mobility. To understand the changes in mobility that occurs with normal aging, or with disease of the central nervous system, we must quantify, characterize and model movements in the natural environment, e.g., in and around the home. 176752,THE MOLECULAR DETERMINANTS OF PROXIMAL TUBULAR CALCIUM ABSORPTION,Alexander  Robert T,"Alexander, Robert T",University of Alberta,Alberta,Canada,200809,300000.0,CIHR Clinician Scientist - Phase 2,Salary Programs,Biomedical,"Nutrition, Metabolism and Diabetes",Calcium Homeostasis; Ion Transport; Kidney Stones; Knockout Mice; Osteoporosis; Proximal Tubule,"Both kidney stone formation and osteoporosis are diseases characterized by increased urinary excretion of calcium. Unfortunately, to date, why certain individuals waste calcium is not known. These studies seek to understand this. The proposed research is specifically aimed at understanding how calcium, once filtered by the glomerulus (individual kidney filter), is reabsorbed back into the proximal tubule. This part of the nephron (single kidney tubule) was chosen as it is where the greatest amount (>60%)of calcium is absorbed from. Previous studies have implicated sodium reabsorption in this process. However, whether the molecular determinants of sodium absorption, mediate calcium absorption has not been directly tested. This will be done both in a tissue culture model of proximal tubular cells and in knockout mice. A sodium transport protein, the epithelial sodium proton exchanger, NHE3, is central to proximal tubular sodium absorption. Therefore its role in calcium reabsorption will be delineated. First in cell culture models, then in NHE3 knockout mice. The latter studies will look for the effects of calcium wasting on the whole animal. Together the proposed research will delineate molecular details of renal calcium regulation and consequently provide insight into renal calcium wasting and its consequences,kidney stones and osteoporosis.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=176752&lang=en

CDRD is the first of its kind in Canada. Its mission is to take drug discoveries from the Universities and Teaching Hospitals of British Columbia and develop them into new medicines to treat diseases. 
The process of drug discovery and development takes a long time and requires the expertise of many different disciplines such as chemistry, biology, etc. Therefore, researchers who are experts in one field often do not have the expertise or the access to the specialized equipment and personnel to move their discoveries from the laboratory to the clinic. This is where CDRD gets involved. CDRD offers both specialized equipment and personnel who are knowledgeable in drug discovery and development. CDRD assists with the identification of disease targets and the drugs that act on them, the development of new, more effective drugs, the formulation of drugs into medicines suitable for human use, and the testing of the medicines to ensure they are effective and safe. Because CDRD offers not only a variety of expertise, but also the latest in equipment and technology, it is an ideal environment to train talented individuals in drug discovery and development. The trainees will take specialized courses and modules. Further, they will become part of multidisciplinary teams working to develop new medicines. They will have a unique opportunity to work with different technologies and alongside colleagues with very different scientific backgrounds to their own. The trainees will not only develop a vast array of scientific skills but also communication and organizational skills. 176853,Implications of activated BMP signalling and Id1/Id3 function in ovarian cancer pathogenesis,Shepherd  Trevor G,"Shepherd, Trevor G",Western University (Ontario),Ontario,Canada,200809,0.0,Operating Grant - Priority Announcement: Ovarian Cancer (bridge funding),Operating Grants,Biomedical,Cancer Research,Bmp Signalling; Id Genes; Ovarian Cancer; Spheroids; Transgenic Mice; Viral Transduction,"Ovarian cancer has one of the highest mortality rates of all cancers in women due primarily to unreliable early detection and ineffective drugs to treat the disease after it has spread. Therefore, the goal of our research is to generate new experimental models for the study of molecules involved in the initiation and progression of ovarian cancer. The molecules we will study are bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signal proteins, and two genes controlled by BMPs, specifically Id1 and Id3. How BMP signals and Id1 and Id3 genes affect the behaviour of normal cells of the ovary and ovarian cancer cells will be studied using three new ""model systems"" being developed in our laboratory:
Aim #1: Collect ovarian cancer cells from patients and grow them in the lab under conditions that imitate how they grow in an ovarian cancer patient--direct molecular and cellular analysis of ovarian cancer cells from patients using this model system will provide more accurate results and thereby generate clinically-relevant insights into the disease;
Aim #2: Establish ovarian tumours on the surface of shell-less chick embryos as a model of ovarian cancer growth--this is a unique opportunity to develop an innovative ""bioassay"" for future testing of new drugs that can be used to treat ovarian cancer patients;
Aim #3: Develop genetically-altered mice which mimic early stages of ovarian cancer--understanding the initial changes that cause normal cells of the ovary to become cancer cells is indispensable to develop new strategies for prevention and early detection of ovarian cancer
These Aims will define the role of BMP signals and Id1 and Id3 molecules in both early and late stages of ovarian cancer, develop innovative experimental models for future research, and potentially identify new and important drug targets to treat women diagnosed with ovarian cancer.",1 yr 3 mths,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=176853&lang=en

177012,Natural killer T cell trafficking in the liver,Wong  Connie H,"Wong, Connie H",University of Calgary,Alberta,Canada,200810,60000.0,CAG/CIHR Fellowship for Research in Gastroenterology/Nutrition,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,Infection and Immunity,Adhesion Molecules; Immunology; Infection; Inflammation; Liver; Natural Killer T Cells; Trafficking,"Natural killer T (NKT) cells are a recently discovered immune cell that is found throughout the body, but predominantly located in the liver. There is a growing body of evidence to suggest that NKT cells are critical in the regulation of many different types of immune responses, ranging from tumour detection to development of autoimmunity and pathogen responses. However, it remains unclear how NKT cells can play such diverse roles from one type of immune response to another. Recently, our laboratory developed a new way of visualising the behaviour of these NKT cells in the liver using spinning disk microscopy. It was observed that these cells roam around the liver in a 'patrolling' manner looking for signs of infection and abnormal tissue. However, the mechanisms responsible for NKT cell trafficking in the liver are unknown and clearly require further attention. Therefore, the aims of this application are: 1) investigate how NKT cells get into the liver after being produced in the thymus; 2) when activated, which molecules are important in inducing firm adhesion of NKT cells leading to the release of cytokines and 3) which cell types in the liver present antigens to NKT cells to mediate infection and autoimmune responses. These experiments will provide us with important insights into the biology of NKT cells. Whatever their mechanism of action, understanding how NKT cells can orchestrate the immune responses will provide opportunities for translation to human diseases.",2 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=177012&lang=en

177116,The genomic and nutritional origins of cardiovascular disease in South Asians,De Koning  A. B. Lawrence,"De Koning, A. B. Lawrence",University of Cambridge (UK),,United Kingdom,200810,150000.0,Fellowship Award - PA:  Population Genetics and Genetic Epidemiology,Fellowship Programs,Social / Cultural / Environmental / Population Health,Genetics,Cardiovascular Disease; Epigenetics; Ethnicity; Gene-Nutrient Interactions; Genetics; Genomics; Nutrition,"People from South Asia (India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka) are at high risk for having a heart attack or stroke at an early age. Compared to white Europeans of the same body mass index, South Asians have more fat around their waists, higher blood cholesterol and a greater prevalence of diabetes. These are strong risk factors for cardiovascular disease, and while it is not entirely clear why these differences exist, unique genetic factors and lifestyle factors may play important roles. South Asians and several other ethnic groups are believed to possess an efficient genetic makeup that causes fat to be stored more easily than in other groups. This so called ""thrifty genotype"" is thought to be an advantage for surviving famine, but a disadvantage in an urban environment where physical activity is uncommon and food is plentiful. South Asians also consume a diet high in simple carbohydrates, which is known to promote obesity and diabetes. Understanding the relative importance of these factors is the major goal of my research. I am interested in discovering the genetic variation (inherited changes in DNA) that is related to the occurrence of cardiovascular disease in this population, but also the dietary factors that pre-dispose South Asians to high risk. My research also seeks to uncover whether the negative effects of diet are enhanced by genetic variation. For example if a group of genetic variants is found to pre-disposes South Asians to obesity, it might be expected that a high carbohydrate diet would increase risk more in these individuals compared to those without the variants. This research has important implications for Canada, where South Asians make up approximately one quarter of all visibile minorities (1.3 million people), but also the world where they make up nearly one fifth (1.5 billion people) of the global population.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=177116&lang=en

Only recently high-density genome wide association studies (GWAS) have provided a successful, systematic and unbiased approach for complex disease risk discovery. GWAS hits to date are providing evidence that regulatory variation accounts for a considerable proportion of risk alleles observed for chronic disease risk since coding variants have been ruled out in over half of the loci. Although the SNPs delineated by GWAS may be used to help identify people with an increased disease risk, full exploitation of the new risk genes require the identification of the causative SNPs to understand disease mechanisms allowing their targeting by novel treatment strategies.
In this study, we propose to detect and map cis-variation in primary human fibroblasts, in regions identified in published GWAS, by measuring the relative expression of each gene allele. Allelic imbalance (AI) will be determined using the novel Illumina BeadArray system and cells will be genotyped using the Illumina Infinium chip. Disease associated regulatory haplotypes, defined by the AI, will then be further followed by us and our collaborators using re-sequencing, fine-mapping, bioinformatics predictions and functional validation of candidate regulatory variants. Ultimately, the identification of susceptibility genetic variants in common diseases will provide a functional basis of disease for pharmacogenetic association, will permit the development of genetic tests to confirm medical diagnostics and will, furthermore, greatly help in our understanding of disease pathogenesis.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=177119&lang=en

Mobility assistive technology, which includes devices such as wheelchairs and bathroom grab bars, helps facilitate participation among these individuals. Although many of these individuals receive assistance from others, scant attention has been paid to the impact of this assistive technology on caregivers. This neglect produces an incomplete portrayal of the benefits of assistive technology, which has significant implications for policy and practice. In order to address this deficiency an experiment will be undertaken that evaluates the effect of an assistive technology updating and tune-up intervention on individuals with stroke and on their caregivers. This intervention involves a detailed in-home assessment of the subject's current assistive technology. This is followed by negotiation and implementation of a personal assistive technology plan with the subjects and their caregivers. We expect this intervention will 1) increase the mobility, well-being, and satisfaction with personal assistance of the individuals with stroke; 2) reduce the amount of caregiver assistance required; and 3) decrease the psychological demands on care givers and increase their satisfaction with caregiving related activities. 72 individuals with stroke and 72 caregivers will be enrolled in the study. Participants will be assigned to either an immediate intervention group or a delayed intervention group.  Outcomes of this assistive technology treatment for individuals with stroke and their caregivers will be measured before and after intervention using a variety of standardized instruments. The evidence produced by this study will enable service providers to offer assistive technology interventions that are more attuned to the needs of both individuals with stroke and their caregivers. 177139,Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein interacts with Rac GTPase to control synaptic growth and function.,Ball  Robin W,"Ball, Robin W",McGill University,Qu&eacute;bec,Canada,200810,45000.0,Fellowship Award - Priority Announcement: Fragile X (SHOPP),Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,"Neurosciences, Mental Health and Addiction",Drosophila; Electrophysiology; Fluorescence Imaging; Fragile X; Genetics; Neuromuscular Junction; Plasticity; Rac Gtpase; Synaptic Development,"Fragile X Syndrome is the most common inherited form of mental retardation.  It is caused by mutations in a single gene called fmr.  The normal product of this gene, the Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein (FMRP), acts as a master regulator of many other proteins by inhibiting their synthesis.  Thus, in individuals with Fragile X Syndrome, proteins that are normally kept at certain, low levels become overabundant, which can have toxic effects.  The particular proteins that are regulated by FMRP are still being investigated, as well as how these misregulated targets lead to the symptoms of Fragile X Syndrome.  We are interested in studying this disease in more detail, by using a disease model in Drosophila fruit flies.  Drosophila are a good model system for human diseases because they have the same cellular pathways as humans but are much simpler and easier to work with than mammals.  Drosophila also has the fmr gene and when it is mutated, it causes defects in the growth and function of synapses between motor neurons and muscle, termed neuromuscular junctions (NMJs).  It has been shown in other systems that FMRP regulates Rac GTPase, which is an important signaling protein that is involved in many cellular processes that control cellular morphology and movement.  We have found that Rac is important for controlling the proper development of NMJs.  If you have too much Rac (as would happen in Fragile X Syndrome) the synapses grow out of control and are hyperexcitable.  Through genetic studies we have discovered that Rac and FMRP do indeed interact at the NMJ and control synaptic growth.  We are now poised to dissect the mechanism of how exactly FMRP regulates Rac signaling and how this leads to changes in the growth and function of neuronal synapses.  Learning more about the basics of FMRP function will hopefully lead to new avenues for medical treatment of Fragile X Syndrome.",2 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=177139&lang=en

Although, long-term sleep disruption most likely contributes to the pathology of FXS, it has yet to be examined systematically. We propose to investigate the relationship between sleep architecture and changes in the brain activity. Sleep is thought to be the price we have to pay for the intense brain activity that occurs during wakefulness. Moreover, sleep plays an important part in memory formation and in ensuring proper maturation of brain cells. In contrast, the FXS brain exhibits immature brain cells, which are thought to underlie the cognitive problems in FXS. Taken together, this information provides a compelling argument for examining the relationship between sleep and synaptic activity in FXS.
