177231,Will increasing APOBEC3G activity in the host cure HIV or cause cancer?,Land  Allison M,"Land, Allison M",University of Minnesota (Minneapolis),Minnesota,United States of America,200810,150000.0,Fellowship - PA: Biomedical / Clinical HIV/AIDS Research,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,Infection and Immunity,Apobec3g; Cancer; Dna Cytosine Deamination; Genomic Mutation; Hiv-1; Hypermutation; Mutagenesis; Nuclear Localization; Retrovirus Restriction; Vif,"The human APOBEC3G protein has the potential to stop the spread of the AIDS virus, HIV.  APOBEC3G's mechanism of lethality involves causing mutations of guanine to adenine in the proviral DNA, which is termed hypermutation.  This can occur so frequently that APOBEC3G literally kills the virus.  However, the full potential of APOBEC3G is rarely realized in patients because HIV fights back with its own protein called Vif, which binds APOBEC3G and triggers its degradation.  This Vif/APOBEC3G interaction would therefore be promising to alter in favour of the host for therapeutic potential.  There is however one very important potential downside to such an approach:  too much APOBEC3G activity may generate cancer-causing mutations.  I therefore hypothesize that there is a critical threshold of APOBEC3G activity that is managed normally by host cells, but activity above this critical level would allow APOBEC3G to enter the host nucleus and cause mutations that could promote cancer.  To test this hypothesis, I will express a range of APOBEC3G protein levels in cell lines and primary cells and monitor APOBEC3G cellular localization (nucleus vs. cytoplasm).  I will also assess the induction of genomic mutations by monitoring reporter gene expression in cell lines for identification of mutations that nullify expression and by identifying the immortalization of primary cells.  The proposed research will determine the possibility of saturating the cell's APOBEC3G threshold.  If it can be saturated, we expect that with increased APOBEC3G expression, the level of APOBEC3G in the nucleus will also increase, as will the level of genomic mutations.  Before novel treatment strategies for HIV are considered that alter APOBEC3G activity or levels, it is imperative to elucidate if increasing APOBEC3G expression will send the promutagenic protein to the nucleus and cause genomic mutations, to help ensure that we do not accidentally design drugs that give people cancer (but cure HIV).",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=177231&lang=en

Pain from arthritis is rarely constant; it fluctuates during the day. Different types of adult arthritis have distinct symptom patterns. Adults with rheumatoid arthritis typically have more pain in the morning, while those with osteoarthritis usually have more pain in the evening. Patterns of pain are important to understand because they help clinicians and researchers understand possible sources of pain aggravation as well as point to potential treatments. In this study, we intend to look at: (a) how pain varies during the day for children with arthritis (b) whether or not pain patterns are associated with components of the disease, such as the amount of inflammation, by general characteristics of the child, such as age and sex, or psychological characteristics of the child, such as mood, or anxiety and (c) whether pain patterns are influenced by other factors such as physical activity. To our knowledge this will be the first study to look at how pain varies during the day in children with arthritis. This study will help clinicians, patients and their families have a better understanding of the pain experience which will lead to better pain management for children with arthritis. 177349,Dynamic chromatin structure controls Anaphase Promoting Complex activity,Islam  Azharul,"Islam, Azharul",University of Saskatchewan,Saskatchewan,Canada,200810,22500.0,Regional Partnership Program Fellowship,Fellowship Programs,Biomedical,Genetics,Apc; Chromatin; Chromatin Dynamics; Chromatin Immunoprecipitation; Gene Expression; Genetic Interactions; H3; H4; Hat; Hdac; Histone Modification; Northern Analysis; Rt-Pcr; Saccharomyces Cerevisiae; Transcription,"Chromatin is a nucleoprotein complex consisting of repeating units of 146 bp of DNA wrapped around a histone H3/H4 tetramer and 2 histone H2A/H2B dimers. Fully assembled chromatin is silent; histones must be post-translationally modified (PTMed) in order to activate gene transcription. Histone PTMs are catalyzed by histone acetyltransferases (HATs) and histone deacetylases (HDACs). These PTMs act as molecular switches for turning on or off  gene transcription. However, much remains to be learned regarding how HATs and HDACs are regulated. Misregulation of chromatin structure, due to altered histone PTMs, results in disease. Therefore, understanding how chromatin structure and histone PTMs are regulated is central to our battle against disease progression. Chemicals that inhibit HDACs (HDACi's) are capable of killing a variety of cancer cells and are now undergoing clinical trials. This clearly demonstrates the importance of histone PTMs to the health of the cell and organism. We have discovered that the Anaphase Promoting Complex (APC), an essential cell cycle regulator, is critical for histone acetylation, genomic stability and normal aging. To understand the role of the APC in histone acetylation, we conducted a genetic experiment using yeast cells showing that the APC required specific HAT and HDAC enzyme function to properly regulate cell cycle progression. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the specific mechanisms involved in how the APC interacts with, and regulates, chromatin structure. We will use the yeast system for these studies due to the ease of genetic and biochemical manipulations. The APC, HATs and HDACs are highly conserved from yeast to humans, making it likely that the knowledge gained from our yeast studies can be directly translated to the human system. These studies could lead to the future identification of relevant clinical therapeutic targets and provide insight into how disease progression in humans can be controlled.",1 yr 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=177349&lang=en

177477,Mechanism of loss of vasodilation response to insulin in type 2 diabetes,Lautt  W. Wayne,"Lautt, W. Wayne",University of Manitoba,Manitoba,Canada,200809,91029.0,CIHR/Regional Partnership Program/Operating Grants,Operating Grants,Biomedical,Circulatory and Respiratory Health,Diabetes; Vascular Dysfunction,"Hormones released in response to a meal result in rapid glucose uptake into skeletal muscle.  This response includes dilation of blood vessels in skeletal muscle that allows increased delivery of glucose to the muscle.  We have recently discovered that the selective uptake of glucose into skeletal muscle is dependent upon a hormone released from the liver in response to insulin.  Insulin administered to healthy rats results in vasodilation of the skeletal muscle only in situations where the hepatic hormone is released.  The vasodilation is actually caused by this hormone and not insulin.  In this study, rats will be made diabetic by providing them with free access to a high sugar drink.  The health of the blood vessels will be assessed at several stages during the development of the disease and the ability of insulin to cause vasodilation secondary to release of the hepatic hormone will be determined. Despite its importance, the current medication-use system suffers from problems related to lack of safety and quality. In order to understand therapeutic and toxic effects of drugs and to continue developing more selective and effective treatments, analysis of drugs in biological samples and pharmaceutical products is growing in importance. Easy determination of unbound and total concentrations of drugs in biological samples is very important for separating population pharmacokinetics from population pharmacodynamics. Altered plasma protein binding is expected in uremia, liver diseases, after surgery, or when displacing drugs are also administered. In these cases, the target total drug concentration should be adjusted to attain the same therapeutically important unbound concentration. The composition of plasma can be subject to considerable differences due to pathological and non-pathological influences. For example, plasma albumin can be decreased to about 50% of the normal level in hepatic diseases and the concentration of lipoprotein-bound triglycerides depends on dietary status. Accordingly, good therapeutic practice should incorporate methods for determination of both free and total drug concentrations, as well as the concentration of drug binding proteins.
Since as many as 70 to 80% of adverse drug reactions are dose related, our success in preventing these adverse reactions is contingent on our ability to conveniently measure drug levels in biological samples, which provides the scientific basis for dose selection.
This research will also expand our understanding about the action of medicinal drugs and will speed up the development of new active compounds. However, DNA is under constant attack from numerous external agents in the environment, such as radiation and chemicals, as well as from essential cellular processes that can generate DNA-damaging free radicals. Damaged DNA that is unrepaired or inaccurately repaired can lead to gross aberrations in DNA, with the resulting potential for the development of cancer or cell death. One of the most deleterious types of DNA damage is the DNA double-strand break (DSB). The major pathway in humans utilized to repair DSBs is nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ), and defects in this repair pathway contribute to the development of cancer and cause extreme sensitivity to DNA damaging agents, such as ionizing radiation. MDD exhibits discordance between monozygotic twins, sexual dimorphism, parent-of-origin effect, and fluctuating disease course - none of which are consistent with DNA sequence-based disease mechanisms.

Epigenetic refers to the regulation of gene expression that are not based on DNA sequence, but rather, controlled by heritable and reversible changes to the DNA (methylation of cytosines) and/or the chromatin structure (modifications of histones). The epigenetic model of major depressive disorder can explain the peculiar characteristics of complex diseases and provide a new interpretation of various non-Mendelian features of MDD. The goal of this study is to understand if and how epigenetic factors are relevant to the aetiological mechanisms of major depressive disorder. This study will be performed on a number of unique samples, which will enable us to interrogate most aspects of MDD using the epigenetic model. Treatment of cancer by chemotherapy and radiotherapy is actually taking advantage of the cell's ability to commit suicide. Chemotherapeutic agents and ionizing radiation both aim at damaging the DNA of cancer cells sufficiently to trigger their death. A better understanding of how the growth and maintenance of these cells is regulated is central to advancing strategies for the treatment and cure of these disorders. We can increase our knowledge in this area by a better understanding of the key genes involved in this processes. One approach to this end is to investigate the ramifications of removing one or more key genes from the organism. In this project, we are studying such a mouse model to find out how a family of genes impacts on the growth, development and maintenance of cells in the intestinal tract. To date, we have found that these genes are needed for the cells lining our intestinal tract to develop properly. We also know that without these genes, mice tend to form tumours in their intestines at a much higher rate than normal. We are currently working to find out precisely how these genes are involved in these processes, so that we can direct this information to potential new modalities for treatments and cures.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=178052&lang=en
178054,Elucidation of a factor found in the probiotic strain Lactobacillus helveticus R0052 critical in inhibiting O157:H7 and other Verocytotoxin-producing Escherichia coli (VTEC) infections.,Ho  Nathan K,"Ho, Nathan K",Hospital for Sick Children (Toronto),Ontario,Canada,200810,33000.0,Doctoral Research Award - PA: Digestive Health (SHOPP),Studentship Programs,Biomedical,Infection and Immunity,E. Coli; Ehec; Lactobacillus Helveticus R0052; Probiotic; Protein Expression; Signal Transduction; Surface Plasmon Resonance; Vtec,"Escherichia coli (E. coli) O157:H7 is the leading cause of foodborne or waterborne infections and outbreaks of haemorrhagic colitis in North America, otherwise known as hamburger disease. The Walkerton tragedy is a recent example of an E. coli O157:H7 outbreak. The human immune system is normally capable of fighting off against bacterial infections, however E. coli O157:H7 has the ability to stop the immune system from turning on. This gives the bacteria time to infect, colonize, and cause disease. In certain conditions, death may result from infection from this bacterium. 

Probiotic foods, such as certain yogurts, have been found to help the body defend against E. coli infection by turning on the body's immune system. However, how this is done is currently unknown. Very recent findings in our laboratory have found that certain probiotic bacteria can generate signals that activate the body's immune system to E. coli. 

If we can identify the signals that the probiotics make, it may be possible to harvest them and infuse them into other foods, especially the ones that E. coli tend to be found in. This could help prevent E. coli infections in the future and avoid other potential outbreaks.",3 yrs 0 mth,https://webapps.cihr-irsc.gc.ca/decisions/p/project_details.html?applId=178054&lang=en
